<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">China</h1> <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div> <div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the People's Republic of China. For the Republic of China, see <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/China_(disambiguation)" title="China (disambiguation)">China (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"PRC" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/PRC_(disambiguation)" title="PRC (disambiguation)">PRC (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">State in East Asia</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<table class="infobox geography vcard" style="width:22em;font-size:88%;"><tbody><tr><th class="adr" colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;padding:0.25em 0.33em 0.33em;line-height:1.2em;font-size:1.25em;"><span class="fn org country-name">People's Republic of China</span><br/><div style="padding-top:0.25em; font-weight:normal;"><span style="font-size:85%;"><span lang="zh-Hans" style="font-style:normal;" title="Chinese language text">中华人民共和国</span> <span class="languageicon" style="font-size:81%;font-weight:normal;">(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_language" title="Simplified Chinese language">simplified Chinese</a>)</span><br/><i>Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó</i> <span style="font-size:85%;">(<a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">Pinyin</a>)</span></span></div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:center;padding:0.5em 0;">
<div style="display:table; width:100%;">

<a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:CN" title="ISO 3166-2:CN">CN</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td>
<div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.cn" title=".cn">.cn</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B" title=".中國">.中國</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD" title=".中国">.中国</a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>China</b>, officially the <b>People's Republic of China</b> (<b>PRC</b>), is a country in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">world's most populous country</a>, with a population of around <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_China" title="Demographics of China">1.404 billion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_21-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-21">[13]</a></sup> Covering approximately 9,600,000 square kilometers (3,700,000 sq mi), it is the third- or fourth-largest country by total area,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[k]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[19]</a></sup> depending on the source consulted. Governed by the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Communist Party of China</a>, the state exercises jurisdiction over 22 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_China" title="Provinces of China">provinces</a>, five <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_China" title="Autonomous regions of China">autonomous regions</a>, four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct-controlled_municipalities_of_China" title="Direct-controlled municipalities of China">direct-controlled municipalities</a> (<a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of China">special administrative regions</a> of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>.
</p><p>China emerged as one of the world's <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization" title="Cradle of civilization">earliest civilizations</a>, in the fertile basin of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> in the <a href="/wiki/North_China_Plain" title="North China Plain">North China Plain</a>. For millennia, China's political system was based on hereditary monarchies, or <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">dynasties</a>, beginning with the semi-legendary <a href="/wiki/Xia_dynasty" title="Xia dynasty">Xia dynasty</a> in 21st century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[20]</a></sup> Since then, China has <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">expanded, fractured, and re-unified</a> numerous times. In the 3rd century BCE, <a href="/wiki/Qin%27s_wars_of_unification" title="Qin's wars of unification">the Qin unified core China</a> and established <a href="/wiki/Qin_dynasty" title="Qin dynasty">the first Chinese dynasty</a>. The succeeding <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a>, which ruled from 206 BC until 220 AD, saw some of the <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="Science and technology of the Han dynasty">most advanced technology</a> at that time, including <a href="/wiki/Papermaking" title="Papermaking">papermaking</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Compass" title="Compass">compass</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[21]</a></sup> along with agricultural and medical improvements. The invention of <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a> and <a href="/wiki/Printing" title="Printing">printing</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> (618–907) completed the <a href="/wiki/Four_Great_Inventions" title="Four Great Inventions">Four Great Inventions</a>. Tang culture spread widely in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, as the new <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">maritime Silk Route</a> brought traders to as far as <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[22]</a></sup> Dynastic rule ended in 1912 with the <a href="/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution" title="Xinhai Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a>, when a <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">republic</a> replaced the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> resulted in a division of territory in 1949, when the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Communist Party of China</a> established the People's Republic of China, a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> on <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">Mainland China</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a>-led government retreated to the island of <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">political status of Taiwan</a>  remains disputed.
</p><p>Since the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">economic reforms in 1978</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_China" title="Economy of China">China's economy</a> has been one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest-growing</a> with annual growth rates consistently above 6 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[23]</a></sup> As of  2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, it is the world's second-largest economy by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">nominal GDP</a> and largest by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[24]</a></sup> China is also the world's largest exporter and second-largest importer of goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaBiggestTrader_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaBiggestTrader-36">[25]</a></sup> China is a recognized <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons state</a> and has the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_active_troops" title="List of countries by number of active troops">largest standing army</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">second-largest defense budget</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChineseNukes_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChineseNukes-37">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI2014_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI2014-38">[27]</a></sup> The PRC is a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> as it replaced the ROC in 1971, as well as an active global partner of <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations#ASEAN_Plus_Three_and_Six" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN Plus mechanism</a>. China is also a leading member of numerous formal and informal multilateral organizations, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organization" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organization">Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO)</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BCIM" title="BCIM">BCIM</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>. China is a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> and a major <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> within Asia, and has been characterized as a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpowers" title="Potential superpowers">potential superpower</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-40">[29]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Names">Names<span id="Etymology"></span><span id="Name"></span></span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_China" title="Names of China">Names of China</a></div>
<table class="infobox" style="width:22em"><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size: 125%; background-color: #b0c4de;">
<b>China</b></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">

<span style="font-size: 1rem"><span lang="zh-Hant" title="Chinese language text"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B" title="wikt:中國">中國</a></span></span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Literal meaning</th><td>
"Middle Kingdom"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[30]</a></sup> or "Central State"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zg_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-zg-42">[31]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<table class="collapsible collapsed" style="padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;font-size: 100%; text-align: left; background-color: #f9ffbc;">Transcriptions</th></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color: #dcffc9;"><a href="/wiki/Standard_Chinese" title="Standard Chinese">Standard Mandarin</a></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hanyu_Pinyin" title="Hanyu Pinyin">Hanyu Pinyin</a></th><td>

Jūng-guó</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Mandarin" title="Help:IPA/Mandarin">IPA</a></th><td>
<span class="IPA" style="white-space:nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Mandarin" title="Help:IPA/Mandarin">[ʈʂʊ́ŋ.kwǒ]</a></span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color: #dcffc9;"><a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">other Mandarin</a></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Xiao%27erjing" title="Xiao'erjing">Xiao'erjing</a></th><td>
<span dir="rtl" lang="zh-Arab" title="Chinese language text">ﺟْﻮﻗُﻮَع</span>‎</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Dungan_language" title="Dungan language">Dungan</a></th><td>
Җунгуй</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sichuanese_Mandarin" title="Sichuanese Mandarin">Sichuanese</a> <a href="/wiki/Sichuanese_Pinyin" title="Sichuanese Pinyin">Pinyin</a></th><td>

<table class="collapsible collapsed" style="padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;font-size: 100%; text-align: left; background-color: #f9ffbc;">Transcriptions</th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/SASM/GNC_romanization#Mongolian" title="SASM/GNC romanization">SASM/GNC</a></th><td>
Bügüde nayiramdaqu dumdadu arad ulus</td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color: #b0c4de;">Uyghur name</th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Uyghur_language" title="Uyghur language">Uyghur</a></th><td>
<div style="direction:rtl;"><span lang="ug" style="font-family:'UKIJ Tuz','UKIJ Nasq','UKIJ Basma','UKIJ_Mac Basma','UKIJ Zilwa','UKIJ Esliye','UKIJ Tuz Basma','UKIJ Tuz Kitab','UKIJ Tuz Gezit','UKIJ Tuz Qara','UKIJ Tuz Qara','UKIJ Tuz Tor','UKIJ Kesme','UKIJ Kesme Tuz','UKIJ Qara','UKIJ Basma Aq','UKIJ Basma Qara','UKIJ Basma Tuz','UKIJ Putuk','UKIJ Tuz Xet','UKIJ Tom Xet','UKIJ Tuz Jurnal','UKIJ Arabic','UKIJ CJK','UKIJ Ekran','UKIJ_Mac Ekran','UKIJ Teng','UKIJ Tor','UKIJ Tuz Tom','UKIJ Mono Keng','UKIJ Mono Tar','UKIJ Nokia','UKIJ SimSun','UKIJ Yanfon','UKIJ Qolyazma','UKIJ Saet','UKIJ Nasq Zilwa','UKIJ Sulus','UKIJ Sulus Tom','UKIJ 3D','UKIJ Diwani','UKIJ Diwani Yantu','UKIJ Diwani Tom','UKIJ Esliye Tom','UKIJ Esliye Qara','UKIJ Jelliy','UKIJ Kufi','UKIJ Kufi Tar','UKIJ Kufi Uz','UKIJ Kufi Yay','UKIJ Merdane','UKIJ Ruqi','UKIJ Mejnuntal','UKIJ Junun','UKIJ Moy Qelem','UKIJ Chiwer Kesme','UKIJ Orxun-Yensey','UKIJ Elipbe','UKIJ Qolyazma Tez','UKIJ Qolyazma Tuz','UKIJ Qolyazma Yantu','UKIJ Ruqi Tuz',FZWWBBOT_Unicode,FZWWHQHTOT_Unicode,Scheherazade,Lateef,LateefGR,'Noto Naskh Arabic','Microsoft Uighur'; font-size:125%; font-feature-settings:'cv50' 1;-webkit-font-feature-settings:'cv50' 1;"> جۇڭخۇا خەلق جۇمھۇرىيىتى </span></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<table class="collapsible collapsed" style="padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;font-size: 100%; text-align: left; background-color: #f9ffbc;">Transcriptions</th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Uyghur_Latin_alphabet" title="Uyghur Latin alphabet">Latin Yëziqi</a></th><td>
Jungxua Xelq Jumhuriyiti</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Uyghur_New_Script" title="Uyghur New Script">Yengi Yeziⱪ</a></th><td>
Junghua Həlⱪ Jumⱨuriyiti</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/SASM/GNC_romanization#Uyghur" title="SASM/GNC romanization">SASM/GNC</a></th><td>
Junghua Hälk̂ Jumĥuriyiti</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Uyghur_Cyrillic_alphabet" title="Uyghur Cyrillic alphabet">Siril Yëziqi</a></th><td>
Җуңхуа Хәлқ Җумһурийити</td></tr></tbody></table></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color: #b0c4de;">Manchu name</th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Manchu_alphabet" title="Manchu alphabet">Manchu script</a></th><td>
<span lang="mnc" style="display:inline-block; font-weight:normal; font-family:'Abkai Xanyan', 'Abkai Xanyan LA', 'Abkai Xanyan VT', 'Abkai Xanyan XX', 'Abkai Xanyan SC', 'Abkai Buleku', 'Daicing White', 'Oyun Gurban Ulus Tig', 'Oyun Qagan Tig', 'Oyun Garqag Tig', 'Oyun Har_a Tig', 'Oyun Scnin Tig', 'Mongolian BT', 'Mongolian Baiti', 'Noto Sans Mongolian', 'Code2000'; font-size: 1.5em; line-height: 1em; -webkit-writing-mode: vertical-lr; -o-writing-mode: vertical-lr; -ms-writing-mode: tb-lr; writing-mode: tb-lr; writing-mode: vertical-lr; vertical-align:text-top;"> ᡩᡠᠯᡳᠮᠪᠠᡳ<br/>ᠨᡳᠶᠠᠯᠮᠠᡳᡵᡤᡝᠨ<br/>ᡤᡠᠨᡥᡝ ᡤᡠᡵᡠᠨ<br/>(ᡩᡡᠯᡳᠮᠪᠠᡳ<br/>ᡤᡠᡵᡠᠨ) </span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Transliterations_of_Manchu" title="Transliterations of Manchu">Romanization</a></th><td>
Dulimbai niyalmairgen gungheg' gurun(Dulimbai Gurun)</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The English word "China" is first attested in <a href="/wiki/Richard_Eden" title="Richard Eden">Richard Eden</a>'s 1555 translation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[l]</a></sup> of the 1516 journal of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_empire" title="Portuguese empire">Portuguese</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_exploration" title="Portuguese exploration">explorer</a> <a href="/wiki/Duarte_Barbosa" title="Duarte Barbosa">Duarte Barbosa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[m]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[36]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">demonym</a>, that is, the name for the people, and adjectival form "Chinese" developed later on the model of Portuguese <i><i lang="pt" title="Portuguese language text">chinês</i></i> and French <i><i lang="fr" title="French language text">chinois</i></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[n]</a></sup> Portuguese <i>China</i> is thought to derive from <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> <i>Chīn</i> (<span lang="fa" title="Persian language text"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%DA%86%DB%8C%D9%86" title="wikt:چین">چین</a></span>), which may be traced further back to <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Chinas" title="Chinas">Cīna</a></i> (<span lang="sa" title="Sanskrit language text"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E0%A4%9A%E0%A5%80%E0%A4%A8" title="wikt:चीन">चीन</a></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AmHer_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-AmHer-53">[39]</a></sup> <i>Cīna</i> was first used in early <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> scripture, including the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81bh%C4%81rata" title="Mahābhārata">Mahābhārata</a></i> (5th century <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>) and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manusm%E1%B9%9Bti" title="Manusmṛti">Laws of Manu</a></i> (2nd century <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wade_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-wade-54">[40]</a></sup> In 1655, <a href="/wiki/Martino_Martini" title="Martino Martini">Martino Martini</a> suggested that the word China is derived ultimately from the name of the <a href="/wiki/Qin_dynasty" title="Qin dynasty">Qin dynasty</a> (221–206 BC),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martini_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-Martini-55">[41]</a></sup> a proposal supported by many later scholars,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[44]</a></sup> although there are also a number of alternative suggestions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wade_54-1"><a href="#cite_note-wade-54">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The official name of the modern state is the "People's Republic of China" (<a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hans"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%8D%8E%E4%BA%BA%E6%B0%91%E5%85%B1%E5%92%8C%E5%9B%BD" title="wikt:中华人民共和国">中华人民共和国</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Zh%C5%8Dnghu%C3%A1_R%C3%A9nm%C3%ADn_G%C3%B2ngh%C3%A9gu%C3%B3" title="wikt:Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó">Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó</a></span></i>). The shorter form is "China" <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Zh%C5%8Dnggu%C3%B3" title="wikt:Zhōngguó">Zhōngguó</a></i> <span class="nowrap">(<span lang="zh" title="Chinese language text"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD" title="wikt:中国">中国</a></span>),</span> from <i><i lang="zh-Latn-pinyin" title="Chinese language text">zhōng</i></i> ("central") and <i><i lang="zh-Latn-pinyin" title="Chinese language text">guó</i></i> ("state"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zg_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-zg-42">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[o]</a></sup> a term which developed under the <a href="/wiki/Western_Zhou" title="Western Zhou">Western Zhou</a> dynasty in reference to its <a href="/wiki/Demesne" title="Demesne">royal demesne</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[p]</a></sup> It was then applied to the area around <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luoyi" title="Luoyi">Luoyi</a> (present-day Luoyang) during the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Zhou" title="Eastern Zhou">Eastern Zhou</a> and then to China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Plain_(China)" title="Central Plain (China)">Central Plain</a> before being used as an occasional synonym for the state under the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-61">[47]</a></sup> It was often used as a cultural concept to distinguish the <a href="/wiki/Huaxia" title="Huaxia">Huaxia</a> people from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hua-Yi_distinction" title="Hua-Yi distinction">perceived "barbarians"</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_61-2"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-61">[47]</a></sup> and was the source of the English name <span class="nowrap">"Middle Kingdom".</span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[50]</a></sup> A more literary or inclusive name, alluding to the "land of Chinese civilization", is <i><i lang="zh-Latn-pinyin" title="Chinese language text">Zhōnghuá</i></i> <span class="nowrap">(<span lang="zh" title="Chinese language text"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%8D%8E" title="wikt:中华">中华</a></span>).</span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[51]</a></sup> It developed during the <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Wei</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sima_Jin" title="Sima Jin">Jin</a> dynasties as a contraction of "the central state of the <a href="/wiki/Huaxia" title="Huaxia">Huaxia</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_61-3"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-61">[47]</a></sup> Before the PRC's establishment, the proposed name of the country was the <i>People's Democratic Republic of China</i> (<a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hans"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%8D%8E" title="wikt:中华">中华</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%BA%BA%E6%B0%91" title="wikt:人民">人民</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B0%91" title="wikt:民">民</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%BB" title="wikt:主">主</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%85%B1%E5%92%8C%E5%9B%BD" title="wikt:共和国">共和国</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF" title="wikt:中華">中華</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%BA%BA%E6%B0%91" title="wikt:人民">人民</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B0%91" title="wikt:民">民</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%BB" title="wikt:主">主</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%85%B1%E5%92%8C%E5%9C%8B" title="wikt:共和國">共和國</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Zhōnghuá Rénmín Mínzhǔ Gònghéguó</span></i>) during the first <a href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Political_Consultative_Conference" title="Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference">CPPCC</a> held on 15 June 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[53]</a></sup> During the 1950s and 1960s, after the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, it was also referred to as "Communist China" or "Red China", to be differentiated from "Nationalist China" or "<a href="/wiki/Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free area of the Republic of China">Free China</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[54]</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_prehistory" title="Chinese prehistory">Chinese prehistory</a></div>
<p>Archaeological evidence suggests that early <a href="/wiki/Hominidae" title="Hominidae">hominids</a> inhabited China between 2.24 million and 250,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[55]</a></sup> The hominid fossils of <a href="/wiki/Peking_Man" title="Peking Man">Peking Man</a>, a <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> who <a href="/wiki/Control_of_fire_by_early_humans" title="Control of fire by early humans">used fire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[56]</a></sup> were discovered in a cave at <a href="/wiki/Zhoukoudian" title="Zhoukoudian">Zhoukoudian</a> near <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>; they have been dated to between 680,000 and 780,000 <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">years ago</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated198_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated198-73">[57]</a></sup> The fossilized teeth of <i>Homo sapiens</i> (dated to 125,000–80,000 <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">years ago</a>) have been discovered in <a href="/wiki/Fuyan_Cave" title="Fuyan Cave">Fuyan Cave</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dao_County" title="Dao County">Dao County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunan" title="Hunan">Hunan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[58]</a></sup> Chinese <a href="/wiki/Proto-writing" title="Proto-writing">proto-writing</a> existed in <a href="/wiki/Jiahu" title="Jiahu">Jiahu</a> around 7000 <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earliest_writing_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-earliest_writing-75">[59]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Damaidi" title="Damaidi">Damaidi</a> around 6000 <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[60]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dadiwan_culture" title="Dadiwan culture">Dadiwan</a> from 5800–5400 <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>, and <a href="/wiki/Banpo" title="Banpo">Banpo</a> dating from the 5th millennium <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>. Some scholars have suggested that the <a href="/wiki/Jiahu_symbols" title="Jiahu symbols">Jiahu symbols</a> (7th millennium <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>) constituted the earliest Chinese writing system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earliest_writing_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-earliest_writing-75">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_dynastic_rule">Early dynastic rule</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">Dynasties in Chinese history</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yinxu.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="466" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Yinxu.jpg/200px-Yinxu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Yinxu.jpg/300px-Yinxu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Yinxu.jpg/400px-Yinxu.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yinxu.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yinxu" title="Yinxu">Yinxu</a>, the ruins of the capital of the late <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a> (14th century <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>)</div></div></div>
<p>According to Chinese tradition, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_dynasties" title="List of Chinese dynasties">first dynasty</a> was the <a href="/wiki/Xia_dynasty" title="Xia dynasty">Xia</a>, which emerged around 2100 <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[61]</a></sup> The dynasty was considered <a href="/wiki/Chinese_mythology" title="Chinese mythology">mythical</a> by historians until scientific excavations found early <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> sites at <a href="/wiki/Erlitou_culture" title="Erlitou culture">Erlitou</a>, Henan in 1959.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[62]</a></sup> It remains unclear whether these sites are the remains of the Xia dynasty or of another culture from the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[63]</a></sup> The succeeding <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a> is the earliest to be confirmed by contemporary records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[64]</a></sup> The Shang ruled the plain of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> in eastern China from the 17th to the 11th century <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[65]</a></sup> Their <a href="/wiki/Oracle_bone_script" title="Oracle bone script">oracle bone script</a> (from c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1500</span> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[67]</a></sup> represents the oldest form of Chinese writing yet found,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[68]</a></sup> and is a direct ancestor of modern <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Shang were conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou</a>, who ruled between the 11th and 5th centuries <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>, though centralized authority was slowly eroded by feudal warlords. Many independent states eventually emerged from the weakened Zhou state and continually waged war with each other in the 300-year <a href="/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period" title="Spring and Autumn period">Spring and Autumn period</a>, only occasionally deferring to the Zhou king. By the time of the <a href="/wiki/Warring_States_period" title="Warring States period">Warring States period</a> of the 5th–3rd centuries <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>, there were seven powerful sovereign states in what is now China, each with its own king, ministry and army.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Imperial_China">Imperial China</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinesische-mauer.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1590" data-file-width="2577" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Chinesische-mauer.jpg/200px-Chinesische-mauer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Chinesische-mauer.jpg/300px-Chinesische-mauer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Chinesische-mauer.jpg/400px-Chinesische-mauer.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chinesische-mauer.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>China's First Emperor, <a href="/wiki/Qin_Shi_Huang" title="Qin Shi Huang">Qin Shi Huang</a>, is famed for having united the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warring_States" title="Warring States">Warring States</a>' walls to form the <a href="/wiki/Great_Wall_of_China" title="Great Wall of China">Great Wall of China</a>. Most of the present structure, however, dates to the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg/200px-Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg/300px-Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg/400px-Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Terracotta_Army" title="Terracotta Army">Terracotta Army</a> (c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 210</span> <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span>) discovered outside the <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum_of_the_First_Qin_Emperor" title="Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor">Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor</a>, now <a href="/wiki/Xi%27an" title="Xi'an">Xi'an</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Warring_States_period" title="Warring States period">Warring States period</a> ended in 221 <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span> after the <a href="/wiki/Qin_(state)" title="Qin (state)">state of Qin</a> conquered the other six kingdoms and established the first unified Chinese state. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_Zheng_of_Qin" title="King Zheng of Qin">King Zheng of Qin</a> proclaimed himself the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Emperor" title="First Emperor">First Emperor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qin_dynasty" title="Qin dynasty">Qin dynasty</a>. He enacted Qin's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legalism_(philosophy)" title="Legalism (philosophy)">legalist</a> reforms throughout China, notably the forced standardization of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_units" title="Chinese units">measurements</a>, road widths (i.e., cart axles' length), and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Chinese_currency" title="History of Chinese currency">currency</a>. His dynasty also <a href="/wiki/Qin%27s_campaign_against_the_Yue_tribes" title="Qin's campaign against the Yue tribes">conquered the Yue tribes</a> in <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[70]</a></sup> The Qin dynasty lasted only fifteen years, falling soon after the First Emperor's death, as his harsh authoritarian policies led to widespread rebellion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bodde1986_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bodde1986-87">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2007_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2007-88">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a <a href="/wiki/Chu%E2%80%93Han_Contention" title="Chu–Han Contention">widespread civil war</a> during which the imperial library at <a href="/wiki/Xianyang" title="Xianyang">Xianyang</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_destroyed_libraries#Human_action" title="List of destroyed libraries">was burned</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[q]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> emerged to rule China between 206 <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">BCE</span></span> and <span class="smallcaps"><span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">CE</span></span> 220, creating a cultural identity among its populace still remembered in the ethnonym of the <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bodde1986_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bodde1986-87">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2007_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2007-88">[72]</a></sup> The Han <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="History of the Han dynasty">expanded the empire's territory considerably</a>, with military campaigns reaching <a href="/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Xiongnu_War" title="Han–Xiongnu War">Central Asia, Mongolia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gojoseon%E2%80%93Han_War" title="Gojoseon–Han War">South Korea</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Han_campaigns_against_Dian" title="Han campaigns against Dian">Yunnan</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Southward_expansion_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="Southward expansion of the Han dynasty">recovery of Guangdong and northern Vietnam</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a>. Han involvement in Central Asia and <a href="/wiki/Sogdia" title="Sogdia">Sogdia</a> helped establish the land route of the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a>, replacing the earlier path over the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a> to India. Han China gradually became the largest economy of the ancient world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[74]</a></sup> Despite the Han's initial decentralization and the official abandonment of the Qin philosophy of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legalism_(philosophy)" title="Legalism (philosophy)">Legalism</a> in favor of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, Qin's legalist institutions and policies continued to be employed by the Han government and its successors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="End of the Han dynasty">end of the Han dynasty</a>, a period of strife known as <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms" title="Three Kingdoms">Three Kingdoms</a> followed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[76]</a></sup> whose central figures were later immortalized in <a href="/wiki/Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Romance of the Three Kingdoms">one</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_Classics" title="Four Classics">Four Classics</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">Chinese literature</a>. At its end, <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Wei</a> was swiftly overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(265%E2%80%93420)" title="Jin dynasty (265–420)">Jin dynasty</a>. The Jin fell to <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Eight_Princes" title="War of the Eight Princes">civil war</a> upon the ascension of a <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Hui_of_Jin" title="Emperor Hui of Jin">developmentally-disabled emperor</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Five_Barbarians" title="Five Barbarians">Five Barbarians</a> then <a href="/wiki/Uprising_of_the_Five_Barbarians" title="Uprising of the Five Barbarians">invaded</a> and ruled northern China as the <a href="/wiki/Sixteen_Kingdoms" title="Sixteen Kingdoms">Sixteen States</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Xianbei" title="Xianbei">Xianbei</a> unified them as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Wei" title="Northern Wei">Northern Wei</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Xiaowen_of_Northern_Wei" title="Emperor Xiaowen of Northern Wei">Emperor Xiaowen</a> reversed his predecessors' apartheid policies and <a href="/wiki/Northern_and_Southern_dynasties#Northern_dynasties" title="Northern and Southern dynasties">enforced a drastic sinification on his subjects</a>, largely integrating them into Chinese culture. In the south, the general <a href="/wiki/Liu_Yu_(warlord)" title="Liu Yu (warlord)">Liu Yu</a> secured the abdication of the Jin in favor of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liu_Song" title="Liu Song">Liu Song</a>. The various successors of these states became known as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_and_Southern_dynasties" title="Northern and Southern dynasties">Northern and Southern dynasties</a>, with the two areas finally reunited by the <a href="/wiki/Sui_dynasty" title="Sui dynasty">Sui</a> in 581. The Sui restored the Han to power through China, reformed its agriculture and economy, constructed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Canal_of_China" title="Grand Canal of China">Grand Canal</a>, and patronized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_China" title="Buddhism in China">Buddhism</a>. However, they fell quickly when their conscription for public works and a <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo%E2%80%93Sui_War" title="Goguryeo–Sui War">failed war</a> with <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Korea</a> provoked widespread unrest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_(detail_of_original).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1800" data-file-width="3600" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg/200px-Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg/300px-Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg/400px-Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_%28detail_of_original%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_(detail_of_original).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A detail from <i><a href="/wiki/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival" title="Along the River During the Qingming Festival">Along the River During the Qingming Festival</a></i>, a 12th-century painting showing everyday life in the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a>'s capital, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bianjing" title="Bianjing">Bianjing</a> (present-day <a href="/wiki/Kaifeng" title="Kaifeng">Kaifeng</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Under the succeeding <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song</a> dynasties, Chinese economy, technology, and culture entered a golden age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[79]</a></sup> The Tang Empire returned control of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Regions" title="Western Regions">Western Regions</a> and the Silk Road,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[80]</a></sup> and made the capital <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an" title="Chang'an">Chang'an</a> a cosmopolitan urban center. However, it was devastated and weakened by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/An_Shi_Rebellion" title="An Shi Rebellion">An Shi Rebellion</a> in the 8th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[81]</a></sup> In 907, the Tang disintegrated completely when the local military governors became ungovernable. The Song dynasty ended the <a href="/wiki/Five_Dynasties_and_Ten_Kingdoms_period" title="Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period">separatist situation</a> in 960, leading to a balance of power between the Song and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khitan_Liao" title="Khitan Liao">Khitan Liao</a>. The Song was the first government in world history to issue paper money and the first Chinese <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">polity</a> to establish a permanent standing navy which was supported by the developed shipbuilding industry along with the sea trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[82]</a></sup> Between the 10th and 11th centuries, the population of China doubled in size to around 100 million people, mostly because of the expansion of rice cultivation in central and southern China, and the production of abundant food surpluses. The Song dynasty also saw a <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confucianism" title="Neo-Confucianism">revival of Confucianism</a>, in response to the growth of Buddhism during the Tang,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[83]</a></sup> and a flourishing of philosophy and the arts, as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Landscape_art" title="Landscape art">landscape art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porcelain" title="Porcelain">porcelain</a> were brought to new levels of maturity and complexity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[85]</a></sup> However, the military weakness of the Song army was observed by the <a href="/wiki/Jurchen_people" title="Jurchen people">Jurchen</a> <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(1115%E2%80%931234)" title="Jin dynasty (1115–1234)">Jin dynasty</a>. In 1127, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Huizong_of_Song" title="Emperor Huizong of Song">Emperor Huizong of Song</a> and the capital <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bianjing" title="Bianjing">Bianjing</a> were captured during the <a href="/wiki/Jin%E2%80%93Song_Wars" title="Jin–Song Wars">Jin–Song Wars</a>. The remnants of the Song retreated to <a href="/wiki/Northern_and_southern_China" title="Northern and southern China">southern China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 13th century brought the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_China" title="Mongol conquest of China">Mongol conquest of China</a>. In 1271, the <a href="/wiki/Mongols" title="Mongols">Mongol</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Kublai_Khan" title="Kublai Khan">Kublai Khan</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan dynasty</a>; the Yuan conquered the last remnant of the Song dynasty in 1279. Before the Mongol invasion, the population of Song China was 120 million citizens; this was reduced to 60 million by the time of the census in 1300.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[87]</a></sup> A peasant named Zhu Yuanzhang overthrew the Yuan in 1368 and founded the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor" title="Hongwu Emperor">Hongwu Emperor</a>. Under the Ming dynasty, China enjoyed another golden age, developing one of the strongest navies in the world and a rich and prosperous economy amid a flourishing of art and culture. It was during this period that <a href="/wiki/Zheng_He" title="Zheng He">Zheng He</a> led the <a href="/wiki/Ming_treasure_voyages" title="Ming treasure voyages">Ming treasure voyages</a> throughout the world, reaching as far as Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early years of the Ming dynasty, China's capital was moved from <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> to Beijing. With the budding of capitalism, philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yangming" title="Wang Yangming">Wang Yangming</a> further critiqued and expanded Neo-Confucianism with concepts of <a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">individualism</a> and equality of <a href="/wiki/Four_occupations" title="Four occupations">four occupations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[89]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Scholar-official" title="Scholar-official">scholar-official</a> stratum became a supporting force of industry and commerce in the tax boycott movements, which, together with the famines and defense against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_invasions_of_Korea_(1592%E2%80%9398)" title="Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–98)">Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–98)</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qing_conquest_of_the_Ming" title="Qing conquest of the Ming">Manchu invasions</a> led to an exhausted treasury.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1644, Beijing was captured by a coalition of peasant rebel forces led by <a href="/wiki/Li_Zicheng" title="Li Zicheng">Li Zicheng</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chongzhen_Emperor" title="Chongzhen Emperor">Chongzhen Emperor</a> committed suicide when the city fell. The Manchu <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a>, then allied with Ming dynasty general <a href="/wiki/Wu_Sangui" title="Wu Sangui">Wu Sangui</a>, overthrew Li's short-lived <a href="/wiki/Shun_dynasty" title="Shun dynasty">Shun dynasty</a> and subsequently seized control of Beijing, which became the new capital of the Qing dynasty.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="End_of_dynastic_rule">End of dynastic rule</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="877" data-file-width="2000" height="88" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg/200px-Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg/300px-Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg/400px-Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 19th-century depiction of the <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping Rebellion</a> (1850–1864)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a>, which lasted from 1644 until 1912, was the last imperial dynasty of China. Its conquest of the Ming (1618–1683) cost 25 million lives and the <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_before_1912#Qing_dynasty_(1644–1912)" title="Economic history of China before 1912">economy of China shrank drastically</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[91]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ming" title="Southern Ming">Southern Ming</a> ended, the further conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Dzungar_Khanate" title="Dzungar Khanate">Dzungar Khanate</a> added Mongolia, Tibet and Xinjiang to the empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[92]</a></sup> The centralized autocracy was strengthened to crack down on <a href="/wiki/Anti-Qing_sentiment" title="Anti-Qing sentiment">anti-Qing sentiment</a> with the policy of valuing agriculture and restraining commerce, the <i><a href="/wiki/Haijin" title="Haijin">Haijin</a></i> ("sea ban"), and ideological control as represented by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literary_inquisition" title="Literary inquisition">literary inquisition</a>, causing social and technological stagnation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[94]</a></sup> In the mid-19th century, the dynasty experienced Western imperialism in the <a href="/wiki/Opium_Wars" title="Opium Wars">Opium Wars</a> with Britain and France. China was forced to pay compensation, open treaty ports, allow <a href="/wiki/Extraterritoriality" title="Extraterritoriality">extraterritoriality</a> for foreign nationals, and cede <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> to the British<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[95]</a></sup> under the 1842 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Nanking" title="Treaty of Nanking">Treaty of Nanking</a>, the first of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unequal_Treaties" title="Unequal Treaties">Unequal Treaties</a>. The <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (1894–95) resulted in Qing China's loss of influence in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, as well as the cession of Taiwan to <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EightNationsCrime02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="511" data-file-width="700" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/EightNationsCrime02.jpg/220px-EightNationsCrime02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/EightNationsCrime02.jpg/330px-EightNationsCrime02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/EightNationsCrime02.jpg/440px-EightNationsCrime02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EightNationsCrime02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">Eight-Nation Alliance</a> invaded China to defeat the anti-foreign <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxers</a> and their Qing backers.</div></div></div>
<p>The Qing dynasty also began experiencing <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_late_anti-Qing_rebellions" title="Timeline of late anti-Qing rebellions">internal unrest</a> in which tens of millions of people died, especially in the failed <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping Rebellion</a> that ravaged southern China in the 1850s and 1860s and the <a href="/wiki/Dungan_Revolt_(1862%E2%80%9377)" title="Dungan Revolt (1862–77)">Dungan Revolt</a> (1862–77) in the northwest. The initial success of the <a href="/wiki/Self-Strengthening_Movement" title="Self-Strengthening Movement">Self-Strengthening Movement</a> of the 1860s was frustrated by a series of military defeats in the 1880s and 1890s.
</p><p>In the 19th century, the great <a href="/wiki/Chinese_emigration" title="Chinese emigration">Chinese diaspora</a> began. Losses due to emigration were added to by conflicts and catastrophes such as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Chinese_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%9379" title="Northern Chinese Famine of 1876–79">Northern Chinese Famine of 1876–79</a>, in which between 9 and 13 million people died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[97]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Guangxu_Emperor" title="Guangxu Emperor">Guangxu Emperor</a> drafted a <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days%27_Reform" title="Hundred Days' Reform">reform plan</a> in 1898 to establish a modern <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, but these plans were thwarted by the <a href="/wiki/Empress_Dowager_Cixi" title="Empress Dowager Cixi">Empress Dowager Cixi</a>. The ill-fated anti-foreign <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> of 1899–1901 further weakened the dynasty. Although Cixi sponsored a program of reforms, the <a href="/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution" title="Xinhai Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a> of 1911–12 brought an end to the Qing dynasty and established the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%9349)" title="Republic of China (1912–49)">Republic of China</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Republic_of_China_.281912.E2.80.931949.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_China_(1912–1949)">Republic of China (1912–1949)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China (1912–1949)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="820" data-file-width="585" height="280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg/200px-Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg/300px-Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg/400px-Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a>, the father of modern China (seated on right), and <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, later <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="President of the Republic of China">President of the Republic of China</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="336" data-file-width="480" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg/200px-1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg/300px-1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg/400px-1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1945_Mao_and_Chiang.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> toasting together in 1946 following the end of World War II</div></div></div>
<p>On 1 January 1912, the Republic of China was established, and <a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> (the KMT or Nationalist Party) was proclaimed provisional president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[98]</a></sup> However, the presidency was later given to <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shikai" title="Yuan Shikai">Yuan Shikai</a>, a former Qing general who in 1915 proclaimed himself <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_China_(1915%E2%80%931916)" title="Empire of China (1915–1916)">Emperor of China</a>. In the face of popular condemnation and opposition from his own <a href="/wiki/Beiyang_Army" title="Beiyang Army">Beiyang Army</a>, he was forced to abdicate and re-establish the republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Yuan Shikai's death in 1916, China was politically fragmented. Its Beijing-based government was internationally recognized but virtually powerless; regional warlords controlled most of its territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[101]</a></sup> In the late 1920s, the Kuomintang, under <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, the then Principal of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Military_Academy" title="Republic of China Military Academy">Republic of China Military Academy</a>, was able to reunify the country under its own control with a series of deft military and political maneuverings, known collectively as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Expedition" title="Northern Expedition">Northern Expedition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[103]</a></sup> The Kuomintang moved the nation's capital to <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> and implemented "political tutelage", an intermediate stage of political development outlined in Sun Yat-sen's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San-min_Doctrine" title="San-min Doctrine">San-min</a> program for transforming China into a modern democratic state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[105]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_warlords_and_military_cliques_in_the_Warlord_Era" title="List of warlords and military cliques in the Warlord Era">political division</a> in China made it difficult for Chiang to battle the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Communists" title="Chinese Communists">Communist</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> (PLA) against whom the Kuomintang had been warring since 1927 in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>. This war continued successfully for the Kuomintang, especially after the PLA retreated in the <a href="/wiki/Long_March" title="Long March">Long March</a>, until Japanese aggression and the 1936 <a href="/wiki/Xi%27an_Incident" title="Xi'an Incident">Xi'an Incident</a> forced Chiang to confront <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_Japan" title="Imperial Japan">Imperial Japan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> (1937–1945), a <a href="/wiki/Theater_(warfare)" title="Theater (warfare)">theater</a> of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, forced an uneasy alliance between the Kuomintang and the PLA. Japanese forces committed numerous <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war atrocities</a> against the civilian population; in all, as many as 20 million Chinese civilians died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[107]</a></sup> An estimated 200,000 Chinese <a href="/wiki/Nanking_Massacre" title="Nanking Massacre">were massacred</a> in the city of Nanjing alone during the Japanese occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[108]</a></sup> During the war, China, along with the UK, the US and the Soviet Union, were referred to as "trusteeship of the powerful"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Justus_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-Justus-126">[109]</a></sup> and were recognized as the Allied "<a href="/wiki/Four_Policemen" title="Four Policemen">Big Four</a>" in the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_by_United_Nations" title="Declaration by United Nations">Declaration by United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[111]</a></sup> Along with the other three great powers, China was one of the four major <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies of World War II</a>, and was later considered one of the primary victors in the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[113]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">surrender of Japan</a> in 1945, Taiwan, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pescadores" title="Pescadores">Pescadores</a>, was returned to Chinese control. China emerged victorious but war-ravaged and financially drained. The continued distrust between the Kuomintang and the Communists led to the resumption of civil war. Constitutional rule was established in 1947, but because of the ongoing unrest, many provisions of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the Republic of China">ROC constitution</a> were never implemented in mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="People.27s_Republic_of_China_.281949.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="People's_Republic_of_China_(1949–present)">People's Republic of China (1949–present)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="History of the People's Republic of China">History of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<p>Major combat in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> ended in 1949 with the Communist Party in control of most of <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>, and the Kuomintang retreating offshore, reducing the ROC's territory to only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwan_(island)" title="Taiwan (island)">Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a>, and their surrounding islands. On 21 September 1949, <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="Chairman of the Communist Party of China">Communist Party Chairman</a> <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prcfounding_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-prcfounding-13">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prcf2_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-prcf2-14">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prcf3_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-prcf3-15">[9]</a></sup> This was followed by a mass celebration in <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square" title="Tiananmen Square">Tiananmen Square</a> on 1 October, which became the new country's first <a href="/wiki/National_Day_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="National Day of the People's Republic of China">National Day</a>. In 1950, the People's Liberation Army succeeded in <a href="/wiki/Landing_Operation_on_Hainan_Island" title="Landing Operation on Hainan Island">capturing Hainan</a> from the ROC<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[115]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Incorporation_of_Tibet_into_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Incorporation of Tibet into the People's Republic of China">incorporating Tibet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[116]</a></sup> However, remaining Kuomintang forces continued to wage <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kuomintang_Islamic_insurgency_in_China_(1950%E2%80%9358)" title="Kuomintang Islamic insurgency in China (1950–58)">an insurgency in western China</a> throughout the 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[117]</a></sup> In modern US history studies, the founding of PRC China is often termed as "the loss of China" as reflected in US state policy documents of the time, which thinkers such as <a href="/wiki/Noam_Chomsky" title="Noam Chomsky">Noam Chomsky</a> call the beginning of <a href="/wiki/McCarthyism" title="McCarthyism">McCarthyism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="320" data-file-width="414" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg/200px-Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg/300px-Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg/400px-Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mao_proclaiming_the_establishment_of_the_PRC_in_1949.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> proclaiming the establishment of the PRC in 1949</div></div></div>
<p>The regime consolidated its popularity among the peasants through land reform, which resulted in the execution of between 1 and 2 million <a href="/wiki/Landlord" title="Landlord">landlords</a> executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[119]</a></sup> China developed an independent industrial system and its own nuclear weapons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[120]</a></sup> The Chinese population almost doubled from around 550 million to over 900 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[121]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Leap_Forward" title="Great Leap Forward">Great Leap Forward</a>, a large-scale economic and social reform project, resulted in <a href="/wiki/Great_Chinese_Famine" title="Great Chinese Famine">an estimated 45 million deaths</a> between 1958 and 1961, mostly from starvation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Akbar2010_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-Akbar2010-139">[122]</a></sup> In 1966, Mao and his allies launched the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, sparking a decade of political recrimination and social upheaval which lasted until Mao's death in 1976. In October 1971, the PRC <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758">replaced the Republic of China</a> in the United Nations, and took its seat as a permanent member of the Security Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Mao's death, the <a href="/wiki/Gang_of_Four" title="Gang of Four">Gang of Four</a> was quickly arrested and held responsible for the excesses of the Cultural Revolution. <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> took power in 1978, and instituted significant <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">economic reforms</a>. The Communist Party loosened governmental control over citizens' personal lives, and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_commune" title="People's commune">communes</a> were gradually disbanded in favor of working contracted to households. This marked China's transition from a planned economy to a mixed economy with an <a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">increasingly open-market environment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_e_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_e-141">[124]</a></sup> China adopted its current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">constitution</a> on 4 December 1982. In 1989, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_at_Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="People's Liberation Army at Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">violent suppression</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">student protests in Tiananmen Square</a> brought sanctions against the Chinese government from various countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Jiang_Zemin" title="Jiang Zemin">Jiang Zemin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Li_Peng" title="Li Peng">Li Peng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhu_Rongji" title="Zhu Rongji">Zhu Rongji</a> led the nation in the 1990s. Under their administration, China's economic performance pulled an estimated 150 million peasants out of poverty and sustained an average annual gross domestic product growth rate of 11.2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_h_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_h-143">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_i_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_i-144">[127]</a></sup> The country formally joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> in 2001, and maintained its high rate of economic growth under <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wen_Jiabao" title="Wen Jiabao">Wen Jiabao</a>'s leadership in the 2000s. However, rapid growth also severely impacted the country's resources and environment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_j_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_j-146">[129]</a></sup> and caused <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protest_and_dissent_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Protest and dissent in the People's Republic of China">major social displacement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_k_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_k-147">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_l_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_l-148">[131]</a></sup> Living standards continued to improve rapidly despite the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" title="Late-2000s recession">late-2000s recession</a>, but centralized political control remained tight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>Preparations for a decadal Communist Party leadership change in 2012 were marked by <a href="/wiki/Wang_Lijun_incident" title="Wang Lijun incident">factional disputes and political scandals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[133]</a></sup> During China's <a href="/wiki/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="18th National Congress of the Communist Party of China">18th National Communist Party Congress</a> in November 2012, Hu Jintao was replaced as <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">General Secretary of the Communist Party</a> by <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XiJinpingLiKeqiang_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-XiJinpingLiKeqiang-151">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[135]</a></sup> Under Xi, the Chinese government began large-scale efforts to reform its economy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC19July2013a_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC19July2013a-153">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[137]</a></sup> which has suffered from structural instabilities and slowing growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9Dec2012_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-9Dec2012-156">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[142]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Xi%E2%80%93Li_Administration" title="Xi–Li Administration">Xi–Li Administration</a> also announced major reforms to the <a href="/wiki/One-child_policy" title="One-child policy">one-child policy</a> and prison system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SlateChina2013_160-0"><a
