href="#cite_note-SlateChina2013-160">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_China" title="Geography of China">Geography of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="990" data-file-width="1152" height="258" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/300px-China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/450px-China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/600px-China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification_system" title="Köppen climate classification system">Köppen climate types</a> of China</div></div></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="958" data-file-width="1280" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg/200px-China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg/300px-China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg/400px-China_100.78713E_35.63718N.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">A composite satellite image showing the topography of China</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG/200px-Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG/300px-Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG/400px-Longji_terrace_-_03.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Longsheng_Rice_Terrace" title="Longsheng Rice Terrace">Longsheng Rice Terrace</a> in Guangxi</div></div></div></div>
<p>China's landscape is vast and diverse, ranging from the <a href="/wiki/Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert">Gobi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taklamakan_Desert" title="Taklamakan Desert">Taklamakan Deserts</a> in the arid north to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">subtropical</a> forests in the wetter south. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Himalaya" title="Himalaya">Himalaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karakoram" title="Karakoram">Karakoram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pamir_Mountains" title="Pamir Mountains">Pamir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tian_Shan" title="Tian Shan">Tian Shan</a> mountain ranges separate China from much of <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow Rivers</a>, the third- and sixth-longest in the world, respectively, run from the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Plateau" title="Tibetan Plateau">Tibetan Plateau</a> to the densely populated eastern seaboard. China's coastline along the Pacific Ocean is 14,500 kilometers (9,000 mi) long and is bounded by the <a href="/wiki/Bohai_Sea" title="Bohai Sea">Bohai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China</a> seas. China connects through the Kazakh border to the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Steppe" title="Eurasian Steppe">Eurasian Steppe</a> which has been an artery of communication between East and West since the Neolithic through the <a href="/wiki/Steppe_Route" title="Steppe Route">Steppe route</a> – the ancestor of the terrestrial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silk_Road_UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" title="Silk Road UNESCO World Heritage Sites">Silk Road</a>(s).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_geography">Political geography</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_China" title="Borders of China">Borders of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China">Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<p>The People's Republic of China is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">second-largest</a> country in the world by land area<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[144]</a></sup> after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, and is either the third- or fourth-largest by total area, after Russia, Canada and, depending on the definition of total area, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[r]</a></sup> China's total area is generally stated as being approximately 9,600,000 km<sup>2</sup> (3,700,000 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[145]</a></sup> Specific area figures range from 9,572,900 km<sup>2</sup> (3,696,100 sq mi) according to the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-archive-164">[146]</a></sup> 9,596,961 km<sup>2</sup> (3,705,407 sq mi) according to the UN Demographic Yearbook,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_Stat_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Stat-16">[10]</a></sup> to 9,596,961 km<sup>2</sup> (3,705,407 sq mi) according to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-19">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_land_border_lengths" title="List of land border lengths">longest combined land border in the world</a>, measuring  22,117 km (13,743 mi) from the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Yalu_River" title="Yalu River">Yalu River</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin" title="Gulf of Tonkin">Gulf of Tonkin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_19-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-19">[12]</a></sup> China <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_China" title="Borders of China">borders 14 nations</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_neighbouring_countries" title="List of countries by number of neighbouring countries">more than any other country</a> except Russia, which also borders 14.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[147]</a></sup> China extends across much of East Asia, bordering <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar (Burma)</a> in Southeast Asia; <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[s]</a></sup> in South Asia; <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> in Central Asia; and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> in <a href="/wiki/Inner_Asia" title="Inner Asia">Inner Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Asia" title="Northeast Asia">Northeast Asia</a>. Additionally, China shares maritime boundaries with <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, Japan, Vietnam, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Landscape_and_climate">Landscape and climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="604" data-file-width="806" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg/200px-%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg/300px-%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg/400px-%E4%B9%9D%E5%AF%A8%E6%B2%9F%E4%BA%94%E8%8A%B1%E6%B5%B7.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Five Flower Sea at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jiuzhaigou_Valley" title="Jiuzhaigou Valley">Jiuzhaigou Valley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mondsichelsee.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Mondsichelsee.JPG/200px-Mondsichelsee.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Mondsichelsee.JPG/300px-Mondsichelsee.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Mondsichelsee.JPG/400px-Mondsichelsee.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Crescent_Lake_(Dunhuang)" title="Crescent Lake (Dunhuang)">Crescent Lake</a> in <a href="/wiki/Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert">Gobi Desert</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dunhuang" title="Dunhuang">Dunhuang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gansu" title="Gansu">Gansu</a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>
<p>The territory of China lies between <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitudes</a> <a href="/wiki/18th_parallel_north" title="18th parallel north">18°</a> and <a href="/wiki/54th_parallel_north" title="54th parallel north">54° N</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitudes</a> <a href="/wiki/73rd_meridian_east" title="73rd meridian east">73°</a> and <a href="/wiki/135th_meridian_east" title="135th meridian east">135° E</a>. China's landscapes vary significantly across its vast width. In the east, along the shores of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a>, there are extensive and densely populated <a href="/wiki/Alluvium" title="Alluvium">alluvial plains</a>, while on the edges of the Inner Mongolian plateau in the north, broad <a href="/wiki/Grassland" title="Grassland">grasslands</a> predominate. Southern China is dominated by hills and low mountain ranges, while the central-east hosts the <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">deltas</a> of China's two major rivers, the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a>. Other major rivers include the <a href="/wiki/Xi_River" title="Xi River">Xi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mekong" title="Mekong">Mekong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur</a>. To the west sit major mountain ranges, most notably the Himalayas. High <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateaus</a> feature among the more arid landscapes of the north, such as the <a href="/wiki/Taklamakan_Desert" title="Taklamakan Desert">Taklamakan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert">Gobi Desert</a>. The world's highest point, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a> (8,848m), lies on the Sino-Nepalese border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[148]</a></sup> The country's lowest point, and the world's third-lowest, is the dried lake bed of <a href="/wiki/Ayding_Lake" title="Ayding Lake">Ayding Lake</a> (−154m) in the <a href="/wiki/Turpan_Depression" title="Turpan Depression">Turpan Depression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's climate is mainly dominated by <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry seasons</a> and wet <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monsoons" title="Monsoons">monsoons</a>, which lead to pronounced temperature differences between winter and summer. In the winter, northern winds coming from high-latitude areas are cold and dry; in summer, southern winds from coastal areas at lower latitudes are warm and moist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[150]</a></sup> The climate in China differs from region to region because of the country's highly complex <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topography</a>.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="573" data-file-width="900" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg/200px-Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg/300px-Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg/400px-Muztagh_Ata_Xinjiang_China.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Muztagh_Ata" title="Muztagh Ata">Muztagh Ata</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kunlun_Mountains" title="Kunlun Mountains">Kunlun Mountains</a> in <a href="/wiki/Taxkorgan_Tajik_Autonomous_County" title="Taxkorgan Tajik Autonomous County">Taxkorgan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1667" data-file-width="2500" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg/200px-Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg/300px-Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg/400px-Sanya_Sun_Photo_by_Dale_Preston.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> coast at <a href="/wiki/Sanya" title="Sanya">Sanya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>
<p>A major environmental issue in China is the continued <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">expansion of its deserts</a>, particularly the Gobi Desert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_au_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_au-171">[152]</a></sup> Although barrier tree lines planted since the 1970s have reduced the frequency of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sandstorms" title="Sandstorms">sandstorms</a>, prolonged drought and poor agricultural practices have resulted in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_dust" title="Asian dust">dust storms</a> plaguing northern China each spring, which then spread to other parts of east Asia, including Korea and Japan. China's environmental watchdog, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Environmental_Protection_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China">SEPA</a>, stated in 2007 that China is losing 4,000 km<sup>2</sup> (1,500 sq mi) per year to desertification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_av_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_av-172">[153]</a></sup> Water quality, <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">erosion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pollution_in_China" title="Pollution in China">pollution control</a> have become important issues in China's relations with other countries. Melting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glaciers" title="Glaciers">glaciers</a> in the Himalayas could potentially lead to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_shortage" title="Water shortage">water shortages</a> for hundreds of millions of people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msnbc_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-msnbc-173">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_China" title="Wildlife of China">Wildlife of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2400" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg/200px-Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg/300px-Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg/400px-Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Giant_Panda_Eating.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Giant_panda" title="Giant panda">giant panda</a>, China's most famous <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_and_protected_species_of_China" title="List of endangered and protected species of China">endangered</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> species, at the <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_Research_Base_of_Giant_Panda_Breeding" title="Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding">Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a></div></div></div>
<p>China is one of 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009a_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009a-174">[155]</a></sup> lying in two of the world's major <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecozone" title="Ecozone">ecozones</a>: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palearctic" title="Palearctic">Palearctic</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indomalaya" title="Indomalaya">Indomalaya</a>. By one measure, China has over 34,687 species of animals and vascular plants, making it the third-most biodiverse country in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[156]</a></sup> The country signed the <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a> on 11 June 1992, and became a party to the convention on 5 January 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[157]</a></sup> It later produced a <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_action_plan" title="Biodiversity action plan">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan</a>, with one revision that was received by the convention on 21 September 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>China is home to at least 551 species of <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_China" title="List of mammals of China">mammals</a> (the third-highest such number in the world),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[159]</a></sup> 1,221 species of birds (eighth),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[160]</a></sup> 424 species of reptiles (seventh)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[161]</a></sup> and 333 species of amphibians (seventh).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[162]</a></sup> Wildlife in China share habitat with and bear acute pressure from the world's largest population of <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i>. At least 840 <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_and_protected_species_of_China" title="List of endangered and protected species of China">animal species are threatened, vulnerable or in danger of local extinction</a> in China, due mainly to human activity such as habitat destruction, pollution and poaching for food, fur and ingredients for <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine">traditional Chinese medicine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[163]</a></sup> Endangered wildlife is protected by law, and as of  2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country has over 2,349 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_China" title="Protected areas of China">nature reserves</a>, covering a total area of 149.95 million hectares, 15 percent of China's total land area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[164]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Baiji" title="Baiji">Baiji</a> has recently been confirmed extinct.
</p><p>China has over 32,000 species of vascular plants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[165]</a></sup> and is home to a variety of forest types. Cold <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coniferous" title="Coniferous">coniferous</a> forests predominate in the north of the country, supporting animal species such as <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">moose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asian_black_bear" title="Asian black bear">Asian black bear</a>, along with over 120 bird species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rough_guide_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-185">[166]</a></sup> The understorey of moist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conifer" title="Conifer">conifer</a> forests may contain thickets of <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a>. In higher montane stands of <a href="/wiki/Juniper" title="Juniper">juniper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxus" title="Taxus">yew</a>, the bamboo is replaced by <a href="/wiki/Rhododendron" title="Rhododendron">rhododendrons</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">Subtropical</a> forests, which are predominate in central and southern China, support as many as 146,000 species of flora.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rough_guide_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-185">[166]</a></sup> Tropical and seasonal <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforests</a>, though confined to <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hainan_Island" title="Hainan Island">Hainan Island</a>, contain a quarter of all the animal and plant species found in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rough_guide_185-2"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-185">[166]</a></sup> China has over 10,000 recorded species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fungi" title="Fungi">fungi</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[167]</a></sup> and of them, nearly 6,000 are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Higher_fungi" title="Higher fungi">higher fungi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_China" title="Environmental issues in China">Environmental issues in China</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Water_resources_of_China" title="Water resources of China">Water resources of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_China" title="Energy policy of China">Energy policy of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang,_China.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang%2C_China.jpg/220px-Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang%2C_China.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang%2C_China.jpg/330px-Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang%2C_China.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang%2C_China.jpg/440px-Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang%2C_China.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang,_China.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Wind_turbine" title="Wind turbine">Wind turbines</a> in <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg/220px-Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg/330px-Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg/440px-Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chang%27an_avenue_in_Beijing.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The traffic in <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a></div></div></div>
<p>In recent decades, China has suffered from <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_China" title="Environmental issues in China">severe environmental deterioration and pollution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ma2002_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ma2002-188">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[170]</a></sup> While regulations such as the 1979 Environmental Protection Law are fairly stringent, they are poorly enforced, as they are frequently disregarded by local communities and government officials in favor of rapid economic development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[171]</a></sup> Urban air pollution is a severe health issue in the country; the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> estimated in 2013 that 16 of the world's 20 most-polluted cities are located in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[172]</a></sup> And China is the country with the highest death toll because of air pollution. There are 1.14 million deaths caused by exposure to ambient air pollution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[173]</a></sup> China is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions">world's largest carbon dioxide emitter</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[174]</a></sup> The country also has significant <a href="/wiki/Water_pollution" title="Water pollution">water pollution</a> problems: 40% of China's rivers had been polluted by industrial and agricultural waste by late 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[175]</a></sup> In 2014, the internal freshwater resources per capita of China reduced to 2,062m<sup>3</sup>, and it was below 500m<sup>3</sup> in the <a href="/wiki/North_China_Plain" title="North China Plain">North China Plain</a>, while 5,920m<sup>3</sup> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Desalination_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Desalination-196">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2004_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2004-197">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>In China, heavy metals also cause environmental pollution. Heavy metal pollution is an inorganic chemical hazard, which is mainly caused by lead (Pb), chromium (Cr), arsenic (As), cadmium (Cd), mercury (Hg), zinc (Zn), copper (Cu), cobalt (Co), and nickel (Ni). Five metals among them, Pb, Cr, As, Cd, and Hg, are the key heavy metal pollutants in China. Heavy metal pollutants mainly come from mining, sewage irrigation, the manufacturing of metal-containing products, and other related production activities. High level of heavy metal exposure can also cause permanent intellectual and developmental disabilities, including reading and learning disabilities, behavioral problems, hearing loss, attention problems, and disruption in the development of visual and motor function. According to the data of a national census of pollution, China has more than 1.5 million sites of heavy metals exposure. The total volume of discharged heavy metals in the waste water, waste gas and solid wastes are around 900,000 tons each year from 2005–2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, China is the world's leading investor in <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_China" title="Renewable energy in China">renewable energy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_commercialization" title="Renewable energy commercialization">its commercialization</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US$" title="US$">$</a>52 billion invested in 2011 alone;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-By2010_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-By2010-199">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black2010_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Black2010-200">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaLeadingEnergy_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaLeadingEnergy-201">[182]</a></sup> it is a major manufacturer of renewable energy technologies and invests heavily in local-scale renewable energy projects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bradsher_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-bradsher-202">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[185]</a></sup> By 2015, over 24% of China's energy was derived from renewable sources, while most notably from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power" title="Hydroelectric power">hydroelectric power</a>: a total installed capacity of 197 GW makes China the <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity#World_hydroelectric_capacity" title="Hydroelectricity">largest hydroelectric power producer</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEA2015_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEA2015-206">[187]</a></sup> China also has the largest power capacity of <a href="/wiki/Solar_power_by_country" title="Solar power by country">installed solar photovoltaics system</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_by_country" title="Wind power by country">wind power system</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEA-PVPS-2016_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEA-PVPS-2016-207">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aweaQ4_2016_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-aweaQ4_2016-208">[189]</a></sup> In 2011, the Chinese government announced plans to invest four trillion yuan (US$619 billion) in water infrastructure and <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalination</a> projects over a ten-year period, and to complete construction of a flood prevention and anti-drought system by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Desalination_196-1"><a href="#cite_note-Desalination-196">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[190]</a></sup> In 2013, China began a five-year, US$277 billion effort to reduce air pollution, particularly in the north of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_China" title="Politics of China">Politics of China</a></div><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_Chinese_provincial_leaders" title="List of current Chinese provincial leaders">List of current Chinese provincial leaders</a></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:left; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg"><img alt="Xi Jinping in 2016.jpg" data-file-height="942" data-file-width="647" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg/115px-Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg/173px-Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg/230px-Xi_Jinping_in_2016.jpg 2x" width="115"/></a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Li_Keqiang_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="Li Keqiang (cropped).jpg" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="367" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Li_Keqiang_%28cropped%29.jpg/100px-Li_Keqiang_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Li_Keqiang_%28cropped%29.jpg/150px-Li_Keqiang_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Li_Keqiang_%28cropped%29.jpg/200px-Li_Keqiang_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="100"/></a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">General Secretary</a><br/>and <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">President</a></small>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Premier</a></small>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Senate_House.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2430" data-file-width="4320" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_Senate_House.jpg/200px-China_Senate_House.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_Senate_House.jpg/300px-China_Senate_House.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/China_Senate_House.jpg/400px-China_Senate_House.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">The <a href="/wiki/Great_Hall_of_the_People" title="Great Hall of the People">Great Hall of the People</a><br/>where the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a> convenes</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zhongnanhai06.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="442" data-file-width="591" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Zhongnanhai06.jpg/200px-Zhongnanhai06.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Zhongnanhai06.jpg/300px-Zhongnanhai06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Zhongnanhai06.jpg/400px-Zhongnanhai06.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">The <a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a>, home and workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">PRC President</a></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">China's constitution</a> states that The People's Republic of China "is a socialist state under the people's democratic dictatorship led by the working class and based on the alliance of workers and peasants," and that the state organs "apply the principle of democratic centralism."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[192]</a></sup> The PRC is one of the world's only <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist states openly endorsing communism</a> (see <a href="/wiki/Ideology_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="Ideology of the Communist Party of China">Ideology of the Communist Party of China</a>). The Chinese government has been variously described as communist and socialist, but also as authoritarian and <a href="/wiki/Corporatism" title="Corporatism">corporatist</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[193]</a></sup> with heavy restrictions in many areas, most notably against <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_China" title="Internet censorship in China">free access to the Internet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">freedom of assembly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reproductive_rights" title="Reproductive rights">the right to have children</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NGO" title="NGO">free formation of social organizations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-213">[194]</a></sup> Its current political, ideological and economic system has been termed by its leaders as the "<a href="/wiki/People%27s_democratic_dictatorship" title="People's democratic dictatorship">people's democratic dictatorship</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">socialism with Chinese characteristics</a>" (which is <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a> adapted to Chinese circumstances) and the "<a href="/wiki/Socialist_market_economy" title="Socialist market economy">socialist market economy</a>" respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communist_Party">Communist Party</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg/200px-HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg/300px-HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg/400px-HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HammerSickle_Tiananmen.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sign in <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square" title="Tiananmen Square">Tiananmen Square</a> marking the 90th anniversary of the Communist Party of China</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">China's constitution</a> declares that the country is ruled "under the leadership" of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Communist Party of China</a> (CPC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[196]</a></sup> As China is a <i>de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a>, the <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">General Secretary</a> (<a href="/wiki/Party_leader" title="Party leader">party leader</a>) holds ultimate power and authority over state and government serving as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramount_leader_(China)" title="Paramount leader (China)">paramount leader</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[197]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elections_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Elections in the People's Republic of China">electoral system</a> is pyramidal. Local People's Congresses are <a href="/wiki/Direct_election" title="Direct election">directly elected</a>, and higher levels of People's Congresses up to the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a> (NPC) are <a href="/wiki/Indirect_election" title="Indirect election">indirectly elected</a> by the People's Congress of the level immediately below.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-a97_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-a97-217">[198]</a></sup> The political system is decentralized, and provincial and sub-provincial leaders have a significant amount of autonomy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cfr_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-cfr-218">[199]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_China" title="List of political parties in China">Another eight political parties</a>, have representatives in the NPC and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Political_Consultative_Conference" title="Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference">Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference</a> (CPPCC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[200]</a></sup> China supports the Leninist principle of "<a href="/wiki/Democratic_centralism" title="Democratic centralism">democratic centralism</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[201]</a></sup> but critics describe the elected National People's Congress as a "<a href="/wiki/Rubber_stamp_(politics)" title="Rubber stamp (politics)">rubber stamp</a>" body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_China" title="Government of China">Government of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_(pixinn.net).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1081" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg/200px-ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg/300px-ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg/400px-ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ForbiddenCity_MaoZedongPortrait_(pixinn.net).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tiananmen" title="Tiananmen">Tiananmen</a> with a portrait of Mao Zedong</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">President</a> is the titular <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, elected by the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Premier</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, presiding over the <a href="/wiki/State_Council_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="State Council of the People's Republic of China">State Council</a> composed of four vice premiers and the heads of ministries and commissions. The incumbent president is <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, who is also the <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">General Secretary of the Communist Party of China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Central_Military_Commission" title="Chairman of the Central Military Commission">Chairman of the Central Military Commission</a>, making him China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramount_leader_(China)" title="Paramount leader (China)">paramount leader</a>. The incumbent premier is <a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a>, who is also a senior member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CPC_Politburo_Standing_Committee" title="CPC Politburo Standing Committee">CPC Politburo Standing Committee</a>, China's <i>de facto</i> top decision-making body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XiJinpingLiKeqiang_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-XiJinpingLiKeqiang-151">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>There have been some moves toward political liberalization, in that open contested elections are now held at the village and town levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-poll_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-poll-223">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_p_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_p-224">[205]</a></sup> However, the party retains effective control over government appointments: in the absence of meaningful opposition, the CPC wins by default most of the time. Political concerns in China include the growing gap between rich and poor and government corruption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_q_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_q-225">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[207]</a></sup> Nonetheless, the level of public support for the government and its management of the nation is high, with 80–95% of Chinese citizens expressing satisfaction with the central government, according to a 2011 survey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[208]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_China" title="Administrative divisions of China">Administrative divisions of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Hong_Kong" title="Districts of Hong Kong">Districts of Hong Kong</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Macau" title="Municipalities of Macau">Municipalities of Macau</a></div>
<p>The People's Republic of China is divided into 22 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_China" title="Provinces of China">provinces</a>, five <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_China" title="Autonomous regions of China">autonomous regions</a>, each with a designated minority group; four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct-controlled_municipality_of_China" title="Direct-controlled municipality of China">municipalities</a>; and two <a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_region" title="Special administrative region">special administrative regions</a> (SARs) which enjoy a degree of political autonomy. These 31 provincial-level divisions can be collectively referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>", a term which usually excludes two SARs of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>. Geographically, all 31 provincial divisions can be grouped into six regions, including <a href="/wiki/North_China" title="North China">North China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northeast_China" title="Northeast China">Northeast China</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_China" title="East China">East China</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Central_China" title="South Central China">South Central China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwest_China" title="Southwest China">Southwest China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northwest_China" title="Northwest China">Northwest China</a>.
</p><p>China considers <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to be <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China">its 23rd province</a>, although Taiwan is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Republic of China</a>, which rejects the PRC's claim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_ap_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ap-228">[209]</a></sup> None of the divisions are recognized by the ROC government, which claims the entirety of the PRC's territory.
</p>
