<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_China" title="Foreign relations of China">Foreign relations of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Peng_Liyuan,_Xi_Jingping,_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago,_April_2017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1367" data-file-width="2048" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jingping%2C_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago%2C_April_2017.jpg/300px-Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jingping%2C_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago%2C_April_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jingping%2C_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago%2C_April_2017.jpg/450px-Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jingping%2C_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago%2C_April_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jingping%2C_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago%2C_April_2017.jpg/600px-Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jingping%2C_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago%2C_April_2017.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Peng_Liyuan,_Xi_Jingping,_Donald_Trump_and_Melania_Trump_at_the_entrance_of_Mar-a-Lago,_April_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chinese President <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> met with U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and their wives at the Mar Lago resort in Florida</div></div></div>
<p>The PRC has diplomatic relations with 175 countries and maintains <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="List of diplomatic missions of the People's Republic of China">embassies in 162</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Legitimacy_(political)" title="Legitimacy (political)">legitimacy</a> is disputed by the Republic of China and a few other countries; it is thus the largest and most populous <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">state with limited recognition</a>. In 1971, the PRC replaced the Republic of China as the sole representative of China in the United Nations and as one of the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_r_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_r-229">[210]</a></sup> China was also a former member and leader of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, and still considers itself an advocate for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_countries" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009-230">[211]</a></sup> Along with Brazil, Russia, India and South Africa, China is a member of the <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> group of emerging major economies and hosted the group's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2011_BRICS_summit" title="2011 BRICS summit">third official summit</a> at <a href="/wiki/Sanya" title="Sanya">Sanya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a> in April 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SCO_(orthographic_projection).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="553" data-file-width="553" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/220px-SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/330px-SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/440px-SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SCO_(orthographic_projection).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organization" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organization">Shanghai Cooperation Organization</a> (SCO)<br/><span style="margin:0; font-size:90%; white-space:nowrap;"><span class="legend-text" style="border:none; padding:1px .6em; background-color:#346733; color:black; font-size:95%; line-height:1.25; text-align:center;"> </span> Members</span> <span style="margin:0; font-size:90%; white-space:nowrap;"><span class="legend-text" style="border:none; padding:1px .6em; background-color:#000080; color:black; font-size:95%; line-height:1.25; text-align:center;"> </span> Observers</span> <span style="margin:0; font-size:90%; white-space:nowrap;"><span class="legend-text" style="border:none; padding:1px .6em; background-color:#800080; color:black; font-size:95%; line-height:1.25; text-align:center;"> </span> Dialogue partners</span> <span style="margin:0; font-size:90%; white-space:nowrap;"><span class="legend-text" style="border:none; padding:1px .6em; background-color:#00A0A0; color:black; font-size:95%; line-height:1.25; text-align:center;"> </span> Observer applicants</span> <span style="margin:0; font-size:90%; white-space:nowrap;"><span class="legend-text" style="border:none; padding:1px .6em; background-color:#00FF00; color:black; font-size:95%; line-height:1.25; text-align:center;"> </span> Disputed territories</span></div></div></div>
<p>Under its interpretation of the <a href="/wiki/One-China_policy" title="One-China policy">One-China policy</a>, Beijing has made it a precondition to establishing diplomatic relations that the other country acknowledges its claim to Taiwan and severs official ties with the government of the Republic of China. Chinese officials have protested on numerous occasions when foreign countries have made diplomatic overtures to Taiwan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[213]</a></sup> especially in the matter of armament sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="443" data-file-width="863" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/220px-Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/330px-Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/440px-Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_relations_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Diplomatic Relations of China</div></div></div>
<p>Much of current Chinese foreign policy is reportedly based on Premier <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Five_Principles_of_Peaceful_Coexistence" title="Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence">Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence</a>, and is also driven by the concept of "harmony without uniformity", which encourages diplomatic relations between states despite ideological differences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keith_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-Keith-234">[215]</a></sup> This policy may have led China to support states that are <a href="/wiki/Rogue_state" title="Rogue state">regarded as dangerous</a> or repressive by Western nations, such as <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, North Korea and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[216]</a></sup> China has a close economic and military relationship with Russia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[217]</a></sup> and the two states often vote in unison in the UN Security Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_relations">Trade relations</span></h4>
<p>In recent decades, China has played an increasing role in calling for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_trade_area" title="Free trade area">free trade areas</a> and security pacts amongst its Asia-Pacific neighbours. China became a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO) on 11 December 2001. In 2004, it proposed an entirely new <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS) framework as a forum for regional security issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_s_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_s-240">[221]</a></sup> The EAS, which includes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN_Plus_Three" title="ASEAN Plus Three">ASEAN Plus Three</a>, India, Australia and New Zealand, held its inaugural summit in 2005. China is also a founding member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organization" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organization">Shanghai Cooperation Organization</a> (SCO), along with Russia and the Central Asian republics.
</p><p>In 2000, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a> approved "permanent normal trade relations" (PNTR) with China, allowing Chinese exports in at the same low tariffs as goods from most other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[222]</a></sup> China has a significant <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_surplus" title="Trade surplus">trade surplus</a> with the United States, its most important export market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_w_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_w-242">[223]</a></sup> In the early 2010s, US politicians argued that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_yuan" title="Chinese yuan">Chinese yuan</a> was significantly undervalued, giving China an unfair trade advantage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_x_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_x-243">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CurrencyManipulator_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-CurrencyManipulator-244">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[226]</a></sup> In recent decades, China has followed a policy of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Involvement_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China_in_Africa" title="Involvement of the People's Republic of China in Africa">engaging with African nations</a> for trade and bilateral co-operation;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_ae_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ae-246">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_af_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_af-247">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_ag_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ag-248">[229]</a></sup> in 2012, Sino-African trade totalled over US$160 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[230]</a></sup> China has furthermore strengthened its ties with major South American economies, becoming the largest trading partner of Brazil and building strategic links with <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has the <a href="/wiki/World_economy" title="World economy">second biggest economy</a> in the world. According to <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a>, China is planning to reduce the average tariff rate on imports from its trading partners by October 2018. In July 2018, China had also cut import tariffs on approximately 1,500 consumer products so as to open up the economy of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Territorial_disputes">Territorial disputes</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_China#International_territorial_disputes" title="Foreign relations of China">Foreign relations of China § International territorial disputes</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="List of wars involving the People's Republic of China">List of wars involving the People's Republic of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="857" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/China_administrative.png/200px-China_administrative.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/China_administrative.png/300px-China_administrative.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/China_administrative.png/400px-China_administrative.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map depicting territorial disputes between the PRC and neighbouring states. For a larger map, <a href="/wiki/Template:PRC_provinces_big_imagemap" title="Template:PRC provinces big imagemap">see here</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Ever since its establishment after the second <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, the PRC has claimed <a href="/wiki/Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free area of the Republic of China">the territories</a> governed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a> (ROC), a separate political entity today commonly known as Taiwan, as a part of its territory. It regards the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Island_of_Taiwan" title="Island of Taiwan">island of Taiwan</a> as its <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China">Taiwan Province</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kinmen" title="Kinmen">Kinmen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Matsu_Islands" title="Matsu Islands">Matsu</a> as a part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fujian_Province" title="Fujian Province">Fujian Province</a> and islands the ROC controls in the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> as a part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hainan_Province" title="Hainan Province">Hainan Province</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guangdong_Province" title="Guangdong Province">Guangdong Province</a>. These claims are controversial because of the complicated <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a>, with the PRC treating the <a href="/wiki/One-China_policy" title="One-China policy">One-China policy</a> as one of its most important diplomatic principles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to Taiwan, China is also involved in other international territorial disputes. Since the 1990s, China has been involved in negotiations to resolve its disputed land borders, including a <a href="/wiki/Sino-Indian_border_dispute" title="Sino-Indian border dispute">disputed border with India</a> and an undefined border with <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>. China is additionally involved in multilateral disputes over the ownership of several small islands in the East and South China Seas, such as the <a href="/wiki/Senkaku_Islands_dispute" title="Senkaku Islands dispute">Senkaku Islands</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Scarborough_Shoal_standoff" title="Scarborough Shoal standoff">Scarborough Shoal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[236]</a></sup> On 21 May 2014 <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, speaking at a conference in Shanghai, pledged to settle China's territorial disputes peacefully. "China stays committed to seeking peaceful settlement of disputes with other countries over territorial sovereignty and maritime rights and interests", he said.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TerritorialDisputes_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-TerritorialDisputes-256">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Emerging_superpower_status">Emerging superpower status</span></h4>
<p>China is regularly hailed as a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpowers" title="Potential superpowers">potential new superpower</a>, with certain commentators citing its rapid economic progress, growing military might, very large population, and increasing international influence as signs that it will play a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Century" title="Chinese Century">prominent global role</a> in the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-40">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[238]</a></sup> Others, however, warn that <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_bubbles" title="Economic bubbles">economic bubbles</a> and demographic imbalances could slow or even halt China's growth as the century progresses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[240]</a></sup>
Some authors also question the definition of "superpower", arguing that China's large economy alone would not qualify it as a superpower, and noting that it lacks the military power and cultural influence of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[241]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Sociopolitical_issues.2C_human_rights_and_reform"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Sociopolitical_issues,_human_rights_and_reform">Sociopolitical issues, human rights and reform</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_China" title="Human rights in China">Human rights in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hukou_system" title="Hukou system">Hukou system</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_welfare_in_China" title="Social welfare in China">Social welfare in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_China" title="Elections in China">Elections in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_China" title="Censorship in China">Censorship in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Feminism_in_China" title="Feminism in China">Feminism in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg/210px-%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg/315px-%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg/420px-%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E6%B8%AF%E4%BA%BA%E7%87%AD%E5%85%89%E9%81%8A%E8%A1%8C%E8%87%B3%E4%B8%AD%E8%81%AF%E8%BE%A6%E6%82%BC%E5%BF%B5%E5%8A%89%E6%9B%89%E6%B3%A2_12.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>March in memory of Chinese <a href="/wiki/2010_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2010 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> laureate <a href="/wiki/Liu_Xiaobo" title="Liu Xiaobo">Liu Xiaobo</a> who died of organ failure while in government custody in 2017</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_democracy_movement" title="Chinese democracy movement">Chinese democracy movement</a>, social activists, and some members of the Communist Party of China have all identified the need for social and political reform. While economic and social controls have been significantly relaxed in China since the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Political_freedom" title="Political freedom">political freedom</a> is still tightly restricted. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">Constitution of the People's Republic of China</a> states that the "fundamental rights" of citizens include <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Right_to_a_fair_trial" title="Right to a fair trial">right to a fair trial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Property" title="Property">property rights</a>. However, in practice, these provisions do not afford significant protection against criminal prosecution by the state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-261">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hrw_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-hrw-262">[243]</a></sup> Although some criticisms of government policies and the ruling <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Communist Party</a> are tolerated, censorship of political speech and information, most notably on the Internet,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnonymousNoMore_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-AnonymousNoMore-264">[245]</a></sup> are routinely used to prevent collective action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[246]</a></sup> In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> ranked China 159th out of 167 states in its Annual World Press Freedom Index, indicating a very low level of press freedom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rsf.org-554_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-rsf.org-554-266">[247]</a></sup> In 2014, China ranked 175th out of 180 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rural migrants to China's cities often find themselves treated as <a href="/wiki/Second-class_citizen" title="Second-class citizen">second-class citizens</a> by the <i>hukou</i> <a href="/wiki/Hukou_system" title="Hukou system">household registration</a> system, which controls access to <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">state benefits</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ruralmillions_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-ruralmillions-268">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hukou_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-hukou-269">[250]</a></sup> Property rights are often poorly protected,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ruralmillions_268-1"><a href="#cite_note-ruralmillions-268">[249]</a></sup> and taxation disproportionately affects poorer citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hukou_269-1"><a href="#cite_note-hukou-269">[250]</a></sup> However, a number of rural taxes have been reduced or abolished since the early 2000s, and additional social services provided to rural dwellers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ni2005_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ni2005-270">[251]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2006_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2006-271">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of foreign governments, foreign press agencies and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NGO" title="NGO">NGOs</a> also routinely criticize <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Human rights in the People's Republic of China">China's human rights record</a>, alleging widespread <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_rights" title="Civil rights">civil rights</a> violations such as detention without trial, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forced_abortions" title="Forced abortions">forced abortions</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[253]</a></sup> forced confessions, <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a>, restrictions of fundamental rights,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_213-1"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-213">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XinBan2012_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-XinBan2012-273">[254]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Capital punishment in the People's Republic of China">excessive use of the death penalty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wp_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-wp-274">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[256]</a></sup> The government has suppressed popular protests and demonstrations that it considers a potential threat to "social stability", as was the case with the <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">Tiananmen Square protests of 1989</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2155" data-file-width="3385" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_%281%29.jpg/200px-On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_%281%29.jpg/300px-On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_%281%29.jpg/400px-On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:On_the_20th_anniversary_of_8964_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Candlelight vigil on the 20th anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">Tiananmen Square protests</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Falun_Gong" title="Falun Gong">Falun Gong</a> was first taught publicly in 1992. In 1999, when there were 70 million practitioners,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Faison_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-Faison-276">[257]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Falun_Gong" title="Persecution of Falun Gong">persecution of Falun Gong</a> began, resulting in mass arrests, extralegal detention, and reports of torture and deaths in custody.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Amnesty2013_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-Amnesty2013-277">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[259]</a></sup> The Chinese state is regularly accused of large-scale repression and human rights abuses in <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>, including violent police crackdowns and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_suppression" title="Religious suppression">religious suppression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[261]</a></sup> At least 120,000 members of China's <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Muslim</a> <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghur</a> minority have been detained in mass <a href="/wiki/List_of_concentration_and_internment_camps" title="List of concentration and internment camps">detention camps</a>, termed "<a href="/wiki/Reeducation_camp" title="Reeducation camp">reeducation camps</a>", aimed at changing the political thinking of detainees, their identities and their religious beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[262]</a></sup> The state has even sought to control offshore reporting of tensions in Xinjiang, intimidating foreign-based reporters by detaining their family members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[263]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Chinese government has responded to foreign criticism by arguing that the right to subsistence and economic development is a prerequisite to other types of human rights, and that the notion of human rights should take into account a country's present level of <a href="/wiki/Economic_development" title="Economic development">economic development</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yqlgro_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-yqlgro-283">[264]</a></sup> It emphasizes the rise in the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Standard_of_living" title="Standard of living">standard of living</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> and average <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> since the 1970s, as well as improvements in workplace safety and efforts to combat natural disasters such as the perennial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a> floods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yqlgro_283-1"><a href="#cite_note-yqlgro-283">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_ao_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ao-285">[266]</a></sup> Furthermore, some Chinese politicians have spoken out in support of democratization, although <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_skepticism_of_democracy" title="Chinese skepticism of democracy">others remain more conservative</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[267]</a></sup> Some major reform efforts have been conducted; for an instance in November 2013, the government announced plans to relax the one-child policy and abolish the much-criticized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Re-education_through_labour" title="Re-education through labour">re-education through labour</a> program,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SlateChina2013_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-SlateChina2013-160">[143]</a></sup> though human rights groups note that reforms to the latter have been largely cosmetic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Amnesty2013_277-1"><a href="#cite_note-Amnesty2013-277">[258]</a></sup> During the 2000s and early 2010s, the Chinese government was increasingly tolerant of NGOs that offer practical, efficient solutions to social problems, but such "third sector" activity remained heavily regulated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[269]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="State-sponsored_slavery">State-sponsored slavery</span></h3>
<p>According to the 2016 Global Slavery Index, an estimated 3,388,400 people are enslaved in modern-day China, or 0.25% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[270]</a></sup> State-sponsored slavery is part of the Chinese penal system, and there are over a thousand slave labour prisons and camps known collectively as the Laogai. Prisoners are not paid at all, and need their families to send money to them. Prisoners who refuse to work are beaten, and some are beaten to death. Many of the prisoners are political or religious dissidents, and some are recognized internationally as prisoners of conscience. Laogai in Chinese means forced labour and reform. A Chinese president said that they want to see two products coming out of the prisons: the man who has been reformed, and the product made by the man. Harry Wu, himself a former prisoner of the Laogai, filmed undercover footage of the Laogai, and was charged with stealing state secrets. For this, Harry Wu was sentenced to 15 years in prison, but only served 66 days before being deported to the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[273]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_China_before_1911" title="Military history of China before 1911">Military history of China before 1911</a> and <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1334" data-file-width="2000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/220px-J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/330px-J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/440px-J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:J-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">PLA air force</a> <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-20" title="Chengdu J-20">Chengdu J-20</a> <a href="/wiki/Stealth_aircraft" title="Stealth aircraft">stealth</a> fighter aircraft</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1334" data-file-width="2000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/220px-Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/330px-Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg/440px-Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Y-20_at_Airshow_China_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Xi%27an_Y-20" title="Xi'an Y-20">Xi'an Y-20</a></div></div></div>
<p>With 2.3 million active troops, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is the largest standing military force in the world, commanded by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Military_Commission_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)" title="Central Military Commission (People's Republic of China)">Central Military Commission</a> (CMC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdep_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdep-293">[274]</a></sup> China has the second-biggest military reserve force, only behind <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. The PLA consists of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Ground_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Ground Force">Ground Force</a> (PLAGF), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Navy" title="People's Liberation Army Navy">Navy</a> (PLAN), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">Air Force</a> (PLAAF), and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Rocket_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Rocket Force">People's Liberation Army Rocket Force</a> (PLARF). According to the Chinese government, China's military budget for 2017 totalled US$151,5 billion, constituting the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">world's second-largest military budget</a>, although the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_share_of_GDP" title="List of countries by military expenditure share of GDP">military expenditures-GDP ratio</a> with 1,3% of GDP is below world average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI2014_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI2014-38">[27]</a></sup> However, many authorities – including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SIPRI" title="SIPRI">SIPRI</a> and the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_Secretary_of_Defense" title="Office of the Secretary of Defense">Office of the Secretary of Defense</a> – argue that China does not report its real level of military spending, which is allegedly much higher than the official budget.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI2014_38-2"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI2014-38">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeq_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeq-294">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a recognized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" title="Nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons</a> state, China is considered both a major regional military power and a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpowers" title="Potential superpowers">potential military superpower</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcder_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcder-295">[276]</a></sup> According to a 2013 report by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Department_of_Defense" title="US Department of Defense">US Department of Defense</a>, China fields between 50 and 75 nuclear <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ICBM" title="ICBM">ICBMs</a>, along with a number of <a href="/wiki/Short-range_ballistic_missile" title="Short-range ballistic missile">SRBMs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChineseNukes_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChineseNukes-37">[26]</a></sup> However, compared with the other four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a> Permanent Members, China has relatively limited <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_power_projection" title="Military power projection">power projection</a> capabilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Martin_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-Martin-296">[277]</a></sup> To offset this, it has developed numerous power projection assets since the early 2000s – its <a href="/wiki/Chinese_aircraft_carrier_Liaoning" title="Chinese aircraft carrier Liaoning">first aircraft carrier</a> entered service in 2012,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J15Carrier_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-J15Carrier-297">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[280]</a></sup> and it maintains a substantial fleet of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Submarines" title="Submarines">submarines</a>, including several <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_submarine" title="Nuclear submarine">nuclear-powered</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_attack_submarine" title="Nuclear attack submarine">attack</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">ballistic missile</a> submarines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[281]</a></sup> China has furthermore established a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/String_of_Pearls_(China)" title="String of Pearls (China)">network of foreign military relationships along critical sea lanes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[282]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has made significant progress in modernising its air force in recent decades, purchasing Russian fighter jets such as the <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-30" title="Sukhoi Su-30">Sukhoi Su-30</a>, and also manufacturing its own modern fighters, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-10" title="Chengdu J-10">Chengdu J-10</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-20" title="Chengdu J-20">J-20</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Shenyang_J-11" title="Shenyang J-11">Shenyang J-11</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shenyang_J-15" title="Shenyang J-15">J-15</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J-16" title="J-16">J-16</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shenyang_J-31" title="Shenyang J-31">J-31</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J15Carrier_297-1"><a href="#cite_note-J15Carrier-297">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009f_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009f-302">[283]</a></sup> China is furthermore engaged in developing an indigenous <a href="/wiki/Stealth_aircraft" title="Stealth aircraft">stealth aircraft</a> and numerous <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">combat drones</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Defense_Update_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-Defense_Update-305">[286]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Air_supremacy" title="Air supremacy">Air</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sea_denial" title="Sea denial">Sea denial</a> weaponry advances have increased the regional threat from the perspective of Japan as well as Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[288]</a></sup> China has also updated its ground forces, replacing its ageing <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a>-derived <a href="/wiki/Main_battle_tank" title="Main battle tank">tank</a> inventory with numerous variants of the modern <a href="/wiki/Type_99_tank" title="Type 99 tank">Type 99 tank</a>, and upgrading its battlefield <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C4ISTAR" title="C4ISTAR">C3I</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C4I" title="C4I">C4I</a> systems to enhance its <a href="/wiki/Network-centric_warfare" title="Network-centric warfare">network-centric warfare</a> capabilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[289]</a></sup> In addition, China has developed or acquired numerous advanced missile systems,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdes_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdes-309">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2008e_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2008e-310">[291]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/2007_Chinese_anti-satellite_missile_test" title="2007 Chinese anti-satellite missile test">anti-satellite missiles</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[292]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cruise_missile" title="Cruise missile">cruise missiles</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[293]</a></sup> and submarine-launched nuclear ICBMs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WashTiNu_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-WashTiNu-313">[294]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a>'s data, China became the world's third largest exporter of major arms in 2010–14, an increase of 143 percent from the period 2005–09.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[295]</a></sup> Chinese officials stated that spending on the military will rise to U.S. $173B in 2018. <a class="external text" href="http://www.foxnews.com/world/2018/03/04/china-says-defense-budget-to-rise-to-173-billion-in-2018.html" rel="nofollow">fox</a>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<p>In August 2018, China tested its first <a href="/wiki/Hypersonic_flight" title="Hypersonic flight">hypersonic flight</a>. The China Academy of Aerospace Aerodynamics (CAAA) claims to have successfully conducted the test with the aircraft Starry Sky-2 that touched a speed of <a href="/wiki/Mach_number" title="Mach number">Mach</a> 6 - which is six times the speed of sound.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_China" title="Economy of China">Economy of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_China" title="Agriculture in China">Agriculture in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP">List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1800" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg/220px-Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg/330px-Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg/440px-Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lujiazui_tallest_buildings.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shanghai_World_Financial_Center" title="Shanghai World Financial Center">Shanghai World Financial Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jin_Mao_Tower" title="Jin Mao Tower">Jin Mao Tower</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Tower" title="Shanghai Tower">Shanghai Tower, Lujiazui</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="737" data-file-width="1563" height="104" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png/220px-Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png/330px-Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png/440px-Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Graph_of_Major_Developing_Economies_by_Real_GDP_per_capita_at_PPP_1990-2013.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>China and other major developing economies by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP per capita at purchasing-power parity</a>, 1990–2013. The rapid economic growth of China (blue) is readily apparent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[297]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shanghaistockexchange.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Shanghaistockexchange.jpg/220px-Shanghaistockexchange.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Shanghaistockexchange.jpg/330px-Shanghaistockexchange.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Shanghaistockexchange.jpg/440px-Shanghaistockexchange.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shanghaistockexchange.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Stock_Exchange" title="Shanghai Stock Exchange">Shanghai Stock Exchange</a> building in <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Lujiazui" title="Lujiazui">Lujiazui</a> financial district. Shanghai has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">25th-largest city GDP</a> in the world, totalling US$304 billion in 2011<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[298]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>China had the largest economy in the world for most of the past two thousand years, during which it has seen cycles of prosperity and decline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[300]</a></sup> As of  2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, China has <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">the world's second-largest economy</a> in terms of nominal GDP, totalling approximately US$10.380 trillion according to the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="Factual statement (March 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In terms of <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) GDP, China's economy is the largest in the world, with a 2014 PPP GDP of US$17.632 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-320">[301]</a></sup> In 2013, its PPP GDP per capita was US$12,880, while its nominal GDP per capita was US$7,589. Both cases put China <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">behind around eighty countries</a> (out of 183 countries on the IMF list) in global GDP per capita rankings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_320-1"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-320">[301]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_history_and_growth">Economic history and growth</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_(1949%E2%80%93present)" title="Economic history of China (1949–present)">Economic history of China (1949–present)</a></div>
<p>From its founding in 1949 until late 1978, the People's Republic of China was a Soviet-style centrally <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a>. Following Mao's death in 1976 and the consequent end of the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> and the new Chinese leadership began to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_reform_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Economic reform in the People's Republic of China">reform the economy</a> and move towards a more market-oriented <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> under one-party rule. <a href="/wiki/Collective_farming" title="Collective farming">Agricultural collectivization</a> was dismantled and farmlands privatized, while foreign trade became a major new focus, leading to the creation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_Economic_Zone" title="Special Economic Zone">Special Economic Zones</a> (SEZs). Inefficient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government-owned_corporation" title="Government-owned corporation">state-owned enterprises</a> (SOEs) were restructured and unprofitable ones were closed outright, resulting in massive job losses. Modern-day China is mainly characterized as having a market economy based on private property ownership,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.eastday_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-english.eastday-321">[302]</a></sup> and is one of the leading examples of <a href="/wiki/State_capitalism" title="State capitalism">state capitalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[304]</a></sup> The state still dominates in strategic "pillar" sectors such as energy production and <a href="/wiki/Heavy_industry" title="Heavy industry">heavy industries</a>, but private enterprise has expanded enormously, with around 30 million private businesses recorded in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abf_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abf-324">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005-325">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2005a_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2005a-326">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abg_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abg-327">[308]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2676" data-file-width="6090" height="88" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg/200px-Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg/300px-Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg/400px-Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alibaba_group_Headquarters.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Headquarters of <a href="/wiki/Alibaba_Group" title="Alibaba Group">Alibaba Group</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou" title="Hangzhou">Hangzhou</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since economic liberalization began in 1978, China has been among the world's fastest-growing economies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[309]</a></sup> relying largely on investment- and export-led growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chinadaily_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-chinadaily-329">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[312]</a></sup> According to the IMF, China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annual_average_GDP_growth" title="Annual average GDP growth">annual average GDP growth</a> between 2001 and 2010 was 10.5%. Between 2007 and 2011, China's economic growth rate was equivalent to all of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a> countries' growth combined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[313]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/3G_(countries)" title="3G (countries)">Global Growth Generators</a> index announced by <a href="/wiki/Citigroup" title="Citigroup">Citigroup</a> in February 2011, China has a very high 3G growth rating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[314]</a></sup> Its high productivity, low labor costs and relatively good infrastructure have made it a global leader in manufacturing. However, the Chinese economy is highly energy-intensive and inefficient;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-China_Quick_Facts_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-China_Quick_Facts-334">[315]</a></sup> China became the world's largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_energy_resources_and_consumption" title="World energy resources and consumption">energy consumer</a> in 2010,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swartz2010_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-Swartz2010-335">[316]</a></sup> relies on coal to supply over 70% of its energy needs, and surpassed the US to become the world's largest oil importer in September 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BusInsEnergyGuide_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-BusInsEnergyGuide-336">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[318]</a></sup> In the early 2010s, China's economic growth rate began to slow amid domestic credit troubles, weakening international demand for Chinese exports and fragility in the global economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, government claimed growth numbers have come under increased scrutiny, with both non-Chinese financial and economic observes as well as Chinese government officials claiming the government has been inflating its economic output. Examples include, the provincial government in <a href="/wiki/Liaoning" title="Liaoning">Liaoning</a> publicly admitted that the government has been <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cooking_the_books" title="Cooking the books">cooking the books</a> when publishing it's economic data from 2011 to 2014, making an overclaim of over 20%. <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>'s trillion yuan GDP claim for 2016, was in fact a third lower, at 665 billion yuan ($103 billion).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[324]</a></sup> Regarding the credibility of official data, <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">china's premier</a> has been quoted as saying the GDP numbers are "man-made" and unreliable and should be used "for reference only".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[325]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal" title="Wall Street Journal">Wall Street Journal</a> survey of 64 select economists found that 96% of respondents think China's GDP estimates don't "accurately reflect the state of the Chinese economy.",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[326]</a></sup> while some analysts claim the Chinese growth rate is overstated by 2-3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[327]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the online realm, China's <a href="/wiki/E-commerce" title="E-commerce">e-commerce</a> industry has grown more slowly than the EU and the US, with a significant period of development occurring from around 2009 onwards. According to <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">Credit Suisse</a>, the total value of online transactions in China grew from an insignificant size in 2008 to around RMB 4 trillion (US$660 billion) in 2012. The Chinese online payment market is dominated by major firms such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alipay_(payment_platform)" title="Alipay (payment platform)">Alipay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tencent#TenPay" title="Tencent">Tenpay</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_UnionPay" title="China UnionPay">China UnionPay</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[328]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="China_in_the_global_economy">China in the global economy</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px">
<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="2" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Share of world GDP (PPP)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[329]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Year
</th>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Share
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1980</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2.32%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1990</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">4.11%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2000
</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">7.40%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2010
</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">13.89%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">2017</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">18.23%
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>China is a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> and is the world's largest trading power, with a total international trade value of US$3.87 trillion in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaBiggestTrader_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaBiggestTrader-36">[25]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_reserves_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Foreign exchange reserves of the People's Republic of China">Its foreign exchange reserves</a> reached US$2.85 trillion by the end of 2010, an increase of 18.7% over the previous year, making its reserves by far the world's largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009b_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009b-349">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[331]</a></sup> In 2012, China was the world's largest recipient of inward <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI), attracting $253 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FDI_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-351">[332]</a></sup> In 2014, China's foreign exchange remittances were $US64 billion making it the second largest recipient of remittances in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[333]</a></sup> China also invests abroad, with a total outward FDI of $62.4 billion in 2012,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FDI_351-1"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-351">[332]</a></sup> and a number of major takeovers of foreign firms by Chinese companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[334]</a></sup> In 2009, China owned an estimated $1.6 trillion of US <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">securities</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2009c_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009c-354">[335]</a></sup> and was also the largest foreign holder of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_public_debt" title="US public debt">US public debt</a>, owning over $1.16 trillion in US <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treasury_bond" title="Treasury bond">Treasury bonds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abe_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abe-355">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hornby2009_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hornby2009-356">[337]</a></sup> China's undervalued exchange rate has caused friction with other major economies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CurrencyManipulator_244-1"><a href="#cite_note-CurrencyManipulator-244">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2008_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2008-357">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2005_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2005-358">[339]</a></sup> and it has also been widely criticized for manufacturing large quantities of <a href="/wiki/Counterfeit" title="Counterfeit">counterfeit</a> goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[341]</a></sup> According to consulting firm <a href="/wiki/McKinsey_%26_Company" title="McKinsey &amp; Company">McKinsey</a>, total outstanding debt in China increased from $7.4 trillion in 2007 to $28.2 trillion in 2014, which reflects 228% of China's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[342]</a></sup> In 2017 the Institute of International Finance reported that China's debt had reached 304% of its GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[343]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="floatright">
<table cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0">
<tbody><tr>
<td><div class="timeline-wrapper"><map name="timeline_8c452c790f7b57b143219a2fa0fd6c2a"></map><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/8c452c790f7b57b143219a2fa0fd6c2a.png" usemap="#timeline_8c452c790f7b57b143219a2fa0fd6c2a"/></div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left; font-size:85%;">Graph comparing the 2014 nominal GDPs<br/>of major economies in US$ billions (<small><a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF</a></small>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[344]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</div>
<p>China ranked 29th in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Index" title="Global Competitiveness Index">Global Competitiveness Index</a> in 2009,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abh_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abh-364">[345]</a></sup> although it is only ranked 136th among the 179 countries measured in the 2011 <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">Index of Economic Freedom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[346]</a></sup> In 2014, <i>Fortune'</i>s <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Global 500</a> list of the world's largest corporations included <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_Chinese_companies" title="List of largest Chinese companies">95 Chinese companies</a>, with combined revenues of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_dollar" title="US dollar">US$</a>5.8 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fortune500_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fortune500-366">[347]</a></sup> The same year, <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> reported that five of the world's ten largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_companies" title="Public companies">public companies</a> were Chinese, including the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_banks" title="List of largest banks">world's largest bank by total assets</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_and_Commercial_Bank_of_China" title="Industrial and Commercial Bank of China">Industrial and Commercial Bank of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[348]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Class_and_income_inequality">Class and income inequality</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_China" title="Income inequality in China">Income inequality in China</a></div>
<p>China's middle-class population (if defined as those with annual income of between US$10,000 and US$60,000) had reached more than 300 million by 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[349]</a></sup> More than 75 percent of China's urban consumers are expected to earn between 60.000 and 229.000 RMB per year by 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[350]</a></sup> According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hurun_Report" title="Hurun Report">Hurun Report</a>, the number of US dollar billionaires in China increased from 130 in 2009 to 251 in 2012, giving China the world's second-highest number of billionaires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[352]</a></sup> China's domestic retail market was worth over 20 trillion yuan (US$3.2 trillion) in 2012<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[353]</a></sup> and is growing at over 12% annually as of  2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[354]</a></sup> while the country's luxury goods market has expanded immensely, with 27.5% of the global share.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abq_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abq-374">[355]</a></sup> However, in recent years, China's rapid economic growth has contributed to severe consumer inflation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[357]</a></sup> leading to increased government regulation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT9.1_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FT9.1-377">[358]</a></sup> China has a high level of economic inequality,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[359]</a></sup> which has increased in the past few decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[360]</a></sup> In 2012, China's official <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini coefficient</a> was 0.474.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gini_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-gini-380">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[362]</a></sup> A study conducted by <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_University_of_Finance_and_Economics" title="Southwestern University of Finance and Economics">Southwestern University of Finance and Economics</a> showed that China's Gini coefficient actually had reached 0.61 in 2012, and top 1% Chinese held more than 25% of China's wealth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[363]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internationalization_of_the_renminbi">Internationalization of the renminbi</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Internationalization_of_the_renminbi" title="Internationalization of the renminbi">Internationalization of the renminbi</a></div>
<p>Following the 2008 global financial crisis, China realized the dependency on the US Dollar and the weakness of the international monetary system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[364]</a></sup> The RMB Internationalization accelerated in 2009 when China established <a href="/wiki/Dim_sum_bond" title="Dim sum bond">dim sum bond</a> market and expanded the Cross-Border Trade RMB Settlement Pilot Project, which helps establish pools of offshore RMB liquidity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[366]</a></sup> In November 2010, Russia began using the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_renminbi" title="Chinese renminbi">Chinese renminbi</a> in its bilateral trade with China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[367]</a></sup> This was soon followed by <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[368]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[369]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-massg_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-massg-389">[370]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[371]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[372]</a></sup> As a result of the rapid internationalization of the renminbi, it became the eighth-most-traded currency in the world in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[373]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_China" title="Science and technology in China">Science and technology in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_space_program" title="Chinese space program">Chinese space program</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_discoveries" title="List of Chinese discoveries">List of Chinese discoveries</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions" title="List of Chinese inventions">List of Chinese inventions</a></div>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;width: 18.0em; border: 1px solid #aabaaa;"><tbody><tr><td style="padding:0.4em 0"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_rocket.png"><img alt="A man in black armor standing in front of a rocket, attached to a stick, with the stick being held up by two X-shaped wooden brackets." data-file-height="358" data-file-width="503" height="110" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Chinese_rocket.png/155px-Chinese_rocket.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Chinese_rocket.png/233px-Chinese_rocket.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Chinese_rocket.png/310px-Chinese_rocket.png 2x" width="155"/></a></td></tr><tr><th style="background: #cb4154;;padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em"><a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_China" title="History of science and technology in China"><span style="color:white">History of science and<br/>technology in China</span></a></th></tr><tr><td class="hlist" style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em;padding-top: 0.2em;">
