</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_science_and_technology_in_China" title="Template:History of science and technology in China"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_science_and_technology_in_China" title="Template talk:History of science and technology in China"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_science_and_technology_in_China&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical">Historical</span></h3>
<p>China was once a world leader in science and technology up until the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>. Ancient <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_discoveries" title="List of Chinese discoveries">Chinese discoveries</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_inventions" title="List of Chinese inventions">inventions</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Papermaking" title="Papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_typography_in_East_Asia" title="History of typography in East Asia">printing</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Compass" title="Compass">compass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Four_Great_Inventions" title="Four Great Inventions">Four Great Inventions</a>), became widespread across East Asia, the Middle East and later to Europe. Chinese mathematicians were the first to use <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Negative_numbers#History" title="Negative numbers">negative numbers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[375]</a></sup> By the 17th century, Europe and the Western world surpassed China in scientific and technological advancement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[376]</a></sup> The causes of this early modern <a href="/wiki/Great_Divergence" title="Great Divergence">Great Divergence</a> continue to be debated by scholars to this day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[377]</a></sup>
</p><p>After repeated <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">military defeats</a> by the European colonial powers and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_war" title="First Sino-Japanese war">Japan</a> in the 19th century, Chinese reformers began promoting modern science and technology as part of the <a href="/wiki/Self-Strengthening_Movement" title="Self-Strengthening Movement">Self-Strengthening Movement</a>. After the Communists came to power in 1949, efforts were made to organize science and technology based on the model of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, in which scientific research was part of central planning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[378]</a></sup> After Mao's death in 1976, science and technology was established as one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Modernizations" title="Four Modernizations">Four Modernizations</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[379]</a></sup> and the Soviet-inspired academic system was gradually reformed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[380]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era">Modern era</span></h3>
<p>Since the end of the Cultural Revolution, China has made significant investments in scientific research,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CWRD_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-CWRD-400">[381]</a></sup> with $163 billion spent on scientific research and development in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBERG10012014_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBERG10012014-401">[382]</a></sup> Science and technology are seen as vital for achieving China's economic and political goals, and are held as a source of national pride to a degree sometimes described as "techno-nationalism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TeNat_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-TeNat-402">[383]</a></sup> Nonetheless, China's investment in basic and applied scientific research remains behind that of leading technological powers such as the United States and Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CWRD_400-1"><a href="#cite_note-CWRD-400">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBERG10012014_401-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBERG10012014-401">[382]</a></sup> Chinese-born scientists have won the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> four times, the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">Physiology or Medicine</a> once respectively, though most of these scientists conducted their Nobel-winning research in western nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[t]</a></sup>
</p><p>China is developing its education system with an emphasis on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/STEM_fields" title="STEM fields">science, mathematics and engineering</a>; in 2009, China graduated over 10,000 Ph.D. engineers, and as many as 500,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BSc" title="BSc">BSc</a> graduates, more than any other country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[389]</a></sup> China is also the world's second-largest publisher of <a href="/wiki/Academic_publishing_in_China" title="Academic publishing in China">scientific papers</a>, producing 121,500 in 2010 alone, including 5,200 in leading international scientific journals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[390]</a></sup> Chinese technology companies such as <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lenovo" title="Lenovo">Lenovo</a> have become world leaders in telecommunications and personal computing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[393]</a></sup> and Chinese <a href="/wiki/Supercomputer" title="Supercomputer">supercomputers</a> are consistently ranked among the <a href="/wiki/TOP500" title="TOP500">world's most powerful</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[395]</a></sup> China is also expanding its use of industrial <a href="/wiki/Robot" title="Robot">robots</a>; from 2008 to 2011, the installation of multi-role robots in Chinese factories rose by 136 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_space_program" title="Chinese space program">Chinese space program</a> is one of the world's most active, and is a major source of national pride.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[398]</a></sup> In 1970, China launched its first satellite, <a href="/wiki/Dong_Fang_Hong_I" title="Dong Fang Hong I">Dong Fang Hong I</a>, becoming the fifth country to do so independently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[399]</a></sup> In 2003, China became the third country to independently send humans into space, with <a href="/wiki/Yang_Liwei" title="Yang Liwei">Yang Liwei</a>'s spaceflight aboard <a href="/wiki/Shenzhou_5" title="Shenzhou 5">Shenzhou 5</a>; as of  2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_astronauts" title="List of Chinese astronauts">ten Chinese nationals</a> have journeyed into space, including two women. In 2011, China's first space station module, <a href="/wiki/Tiangong-1" title="Tiangong-1">Tiangong-1</a>, was launched, marking the first step in a project to assemble <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_space_station" title="Chinese space station">a large manned station</a> by the early 2020s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[400]</a></sup> In 2013, China successfully landed the <a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_3" title="Chang'e 3">Chang'e 3</a> lander and <a href="/wiki/Yutu_(rover)" title="Yutu (rover)">Yutu</a> rover onto the lunar surface; China plans to collect lunar soil samples by 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[401]</a></sup> In 2016, China's 2nd space station module, <a href="/wiki/Tiangong-2" title="Tiangong-2">Tiangong-2</a>, was launched from <a href="/wiki/Jiuquan_Satellite_Launch_Center" title="Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center">Jiuquan</a> aboard a <a href="/wiki/Long_March_2F" title="Long March 2F">Long March 2F</a> rocket on 15 September 2016. Then <a href="/wiki/Shenzhou_11" title="Shenzhou 11">Shenzhou 11</a> successfully docked with Tiangong-2 on 19 October 2016.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications">Telecommunications</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1423" data-file-width="1039" height="233" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg/170px-The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg/255px-The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg/340px-The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/List_of_BeiDou_satellites" title="List of BeiDou satellites">Beidou satellites</a> are mainly launched using Long March 3 rocket family.</div></div></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_China" title="Telecommunications in China">Telecommunications in China</a></div>
<p>China currently has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_mobile_phones_in_use" title="List of countries by number of mobile phones in use">largest number of active cellphones</a> of any country in the world, with over 1 billion users by February 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[402]</a></sup> It also has the world's largest number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">internet</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_broadband_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of broadband Internet users">broadband users</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barboza2008_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barboza2008-423">[403]</a></sup> with over 688 million internet users as of  2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, equivalent to around half of its population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-InternetSpeed_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-InternetSpeed-424">[404]</a></sup> The national average broadband connection speed is 9.46 Mbit/s, ranking China 91st in the world in terms of internet speed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-InternetSpeed_424-1"><a href="#cite_note-InternetSpeed-424">[404]</a></sup> As of  July 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, China accounts for 24% of the world's internet-connected devices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[405]</a></sup> Since 2011 China is the nation with the most installed telecommunication bandwidth in the world. By 2014, China hosts more than twice as much national bandwidth potential than the U.S., the historical leader in terms of installed telecommunication bandwidth (China: 29% versus US:13% of the global total).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HilbertBitsDivide_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-HilbertBitsDivide-426">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/China_Telecom" title="China Telecom">China Telecom</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_Unicom" title="China Unicom">China Unicom</a>, the world's two largest broadband providers, accounted for 20% of global broadband subscribers. China Telecom alone serves more than 50 million broadband subscribers, while China Unicom serves more than 40 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abca_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abca-427">[407]</a></sup> Several Chinese telecommunications companies, most notably <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> and <a href="/wiki/ZTE" title="ZTE">ZTE</a>, have been accused of spying for the Chinese military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>China is developing its own <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">satellite navigation</a> system, dubbed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beidou_navigation_system" title="Beidou navigation system">Beidou</a>, which began offering commercial navigation services across Asia in 2012,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CustomersDec2012_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-CustomersDec2012-429">[409]</a></sup> and is planned to offer global coverage by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[410]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_China" title="Transport in China">Transport in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2000" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg/200px-Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg/300px-Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg/400px-Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Balinghe_Bridge-3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Baling_River_Bridge" title="Baling River Bridge">Baling River Bridge</a> is one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_highest_bridges_in_the_world" title="List of highest bridges in the world">highest bridges in the world</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Since the late 1990s, China's national road network has been significantly expanded through the creation of a network of <a href="/wiki/China_National_Highways" title="China National Highways">national highways</a> and <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_China" title="Expressways of China">expressways</a>. In 2011 China's highways had reached a total length of 85,000 km (53,000 mi), making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size" title="List of countries by road network size">longest highway system in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[411]</a></sup> In 1991, there were only six bridges across the main stretch of the Yangtze River, which bisects the country into northern and southern halves. By October 2014, there were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River_bridges_and_tunnels" title="Yangtze River bridges and tunnels">81 such bridges and tunnels</a>.
</p><p>China has the world's largest market for automobiles, having surpassed the United States in both auto sales and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">production</a>. Auto sales in 2009 exceeded 13.6 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2010c_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2010c-432">[412]</a></sup> and may reach 40 million by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[413]</a></sup> A side-effect of the rapid growth of China's road network has been a significant rise in traffic accidents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[414]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Rules_of_the_road_in_China" title="Rules of the road in China">poorly enforced traffic laws</a> cited as a possible cause—in 2011 alone, around 62,000 Chinese died in road accidents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[415]</a></sup> In urban areas, bicycles remain a common mode of transport, despite the increasing prevalence of automobiles – as of  2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are approximately 470 million bicycles in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470MBikes_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-470MBikes-436">[416]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PEKT3E.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="733" data-file-width="1024" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/PEKT3E.jpg/200px-PEKT3E.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/PEKT3E.jpg/300px-PEKT3E.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/PEKT3E.jpg/400px-PEKT3E.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PEKT3E.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Terminal 3 of <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">Beijing Capital International Airport</a> is the 2nd-largest airport terminal in the world</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_China" title="Rail transport in China">China's railways</a>, which are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_Railway_Corporation" title="China Railway Corporation">state-owned</a>, are among <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rail_usage_statistics_by_country" title="Rail usage statistics by country">the busiest in the world</a>, handling a quarter of the world's rail traffic volume on only 6 percent of the world's tracks in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overcrowding_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-overcrowding-438">[418]</a></sup> As of  2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country had 103,144 km (64,091 mi) of railways, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size" title="List of countries by rail transport network size">third longest network in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_stats_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013_stats-439">[419]</a></sup> All provinces and regions are connected to the rail network except <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>. The railways strain to meet enormous demand particularly during the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_New_Year" title="Chinese New Year">Chinese New Year</a> holiday, when the <a href="/wiki/Chunyun" title="Chunyun">world's largest annual human migration</a> takes place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overcrowding_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-overcrowding-438">[418]</a></sup> In 2013, Chinese railways delivered 2.106 billion passenger trips, generating 1,059.56 billion passenger-kilometers and carried 3.967 billion tons of freight, generating 2,917.4 billion cargo tons-kilometers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_stats_439-1"><a href="#cite_note-2013_stats-439">[419]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_China" title="High-speed rail in China">high-speed rail (HSR) system</a> started construction in the early 2000s. Today it has over 19,000 kilometers (11,806 miles) of dedicated lines alone, a length that exceeds rest of the world's high-speed rail tracks combined,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[420]</a></sup> making it the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_by_country" title="High-speed rail by country">longest HSR network in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_HSR_stat_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013_HSR_stat-441">[421]</a></sup> With an annual ridership of over 1.1 billion passengers in 2015 it is the world's busiest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[422]</a></sup> The network includes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Guangzhou%E2%80%93Shenzhen%E2%80%93Hong_Kong_High-Speed_Railway" title="Beijing–Guangzhou–Shenzhen–Hong Kong High-Speed Railway">Beijing–Guangzhou–Shenzhen High-Speed Railway</a>, the single longest HSR line in the world, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Shanghai_High-Speed_Railway" title="Beijing–Shanghai High-Speed Railway">Beijing–Shanghai High-Speed Railway</a>, which has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_longest_bridges_in_the_world" title="List of longest bridges in the world">three of longest railroad bridges in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[423]</a></sup> The HSR track network is set to reach approximately 16,000 km (9,900 mi) by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFPviaRaw_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFPviaRaw-444">[424]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Maglev_Train" title="Shanghai Maglev Train">Shanghai Maglev Train</a>, which reaches 431 km/h (268 mph), is the fastest commercial train service in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_maglev_train_coming_out,_Pudong_International_Airport,_Shanghai.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1259" data-file-width="2338" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/A_maglev_train_coming_out%2C_Pudong_International_Airport%2C_Shanghai.jpg/200px-A_maglev_train_coming_out%2C_Pudong_International_Airport%2C_Shanghai.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/A_maglev_train_coming_out%2C_Pudong_International_Airport%2C_Shanghai.jpg/300px-A_maglev_train_coming_out%2C_Pudong_International_Airport%2C_Shanghai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/A_maglev_train_coming_out%2C_Pudong_International_Airport%2C_Shanghai.jpg/400px-A_maglev_train_coming_out%2C_Pudong_International_Airport%2C_Shanghai.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_maglev_train_coming_out,_Pudong_International_Airport,_Shanghai.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Maglev_Train" title="Shanghai Maglev Train">Shanghai Maglev Train</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since 2000, the growth of rapid transit systems in Chinese cities has accelerated. As of  January 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 26 Chinese cities have <a href="/wiki/Urban_rail_transit_in_China" title="Urban rail transit in China">urban mass transit systems</a> in operation and 39 more have metro systems approved<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[426]</a></sup> with a dozen more to join them by 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[427]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Subway" title="Beijing Subway">Beijing Subway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou_Metro" title="Guangzhou Metro">Guangzhou Metro</a>, <a href="/wiki/MTR" title="MTR">Hong Kong MTR</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen_Metro" title="Shenzhen Metro">Shenzhen Metro</a> are among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metro_systems" title="List of metro systems">longest</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides" title="Metro systems by annual passenger rides">busiest</a> in the world.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CR400AF-2001@BJN_(20170626110730).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3680" data-file-width="5520" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/CR400AF-2001%40BJN_%2820170626110730%29.jpg/200px-CR400AF-2001%40BJN_%2820170626110730%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/CR400AF-2001%40BJN_%2820170626110730%29.jpg/300px-CR400AF-2001%40BJN_%2820170626110730%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/CR400AF-2001%40BJN_%2820170626110730%29.jpg/400px-CR400AF-2001%40BJN_%2820170626110730%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CR400AF-2001@BJN_(20170626110730).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuxing_Hao" title="Fuxing Hao">China Standardized EMU</a>, also known as <i>Fuxing Hao</i>, is an indigenous Chinese <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">bullet train</a> whose maximum operating speed reaches 350 km/h (217 mph)</div></div></div>
<p>There were <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_China" title="List of airports in China">approximately 200 airports in 2015</a> with around 240 planned by 2020. More than two-thirds of the airports under construction worldwide in 2013 were in China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-airlines_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-airlines-448">[428]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Boeing" title="Boeing">Boeing</a> expects that China's fleet of active commercial aircraft in China will grow from 1,910 in 2011 to 5,980 in 2031.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-airlines_448-1"><a href="#cite_note-airlines-448">[428]</a></sup> With rapid expansion in <a href="/wiki/Civil_aviation_in_China" title="Civil aviation in China">civil aviation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_China" title="List of the busiest airports in China">largest airports in China</a> have also joined the ranks of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airport" title="World's busiest airport">busiest in the world</a>. In 2013, Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">Capital Airport</a> ranked second in the world by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">passenger traffic</a> (it was 26th in 2002). Since 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_International_Airport" title="Hong Kong International Airport">Hong Kong International Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Pudong_International_Airport" title="Shanghai Pudong International Airport">Shanghai Pudong International Airport</a> have ranked first and third in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_cargo_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by cargo traffic">air cargo tonnage</a>.
</p><p>Some 80% of China's airspace remains restricted for <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">military use</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_China" title="List of airlines of China">Chinese airlines</a> made up eight of the 10 worst-performing Asian airlines in terms of delays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[429]</a></sup>
China has over 2,000 <a href="/wiki/List_of_ports_in_China" title="List of ports in China">river and seaports</a>, about 130 of which are open to foreign shipping. In 2012, the Ports of <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Shanghai" title="Port of Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Hong_Kong" title="Port of Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Shenzhen" title="Port of Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Ningbo-Zhoushan" title="Port of Ningbo-Zhoushan">Ningbo-Zhoushan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Guangzhou" title="Port of Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_of_Qingdao" title="Port of Qingdao">Qingdao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tianjin" title="Port of Tianjin">Tianjin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Dalian" title="Port of Dalian">Dalian</a> ranked in the top in the world <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">in container traffic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">cargo tonnage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[430]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:908px;">
<div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panorama_Yangshan.jpg" title="The Port of Shanghai's deep water harbor on Yangshan Island in the Hangzhou Bay became the world's busiest container port in 2010"><img alt="" data-file-height="2170" data-file-width="11435" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Panorama_Yangshan.jpg/900px-Panorama_Yangshan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Panorama_Yangshan.jpg/1350px-Panorama_Yangshan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Panorama_Yangshan.jpg/1800px-Panorama_Yangshan.jpg 2x" width="900"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_Yangshan.jpg" title="File:Panorama Yangshan.jpg"> </a></div><center>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Shanghai" title="Port of Shanghai">Port of Shanghai</a>'s deep water harbor on <a href="/wiki/Yangshan_Port" title="Yangshan Port">Yangshan Island</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou_Bay" title="Hangzhou Bay">Hangzhou Bay</a> became the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_world%27s_busiest_container_ports" title="List of world's busiest container ports">world's busiest container port</a> in 2010</center></div>
</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_China" title="Water supply and sanitation in China">Water supply and sanitation in China</a></div>
<p>Water supply and sanitation infrastructure in China is facing challenges such as rapid urbanization, as well as <a href="/wiki/Water_resources_of_China" title="Water resources of China">water scarcity, contamination, and pollution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Water_Scarcity_in_China_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-Water_Scarcity_in_China-451">[431]</a></sup> According to data presented by the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Monitoring_Programme_for_Water_Supply_and_Sanitation" title="Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation">Joint Monitoring Program for Water Supply and Sanitation</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">WHO</a> and <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a> in 2015, about 36% of the rural population in China still did not have access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[432]</a></sup> In June 2010, there were 1,519 <a href="/wiki/Sewage_treatment" title="Sewage treatment">sewage treatment plants</a> in China and 18 plants were added each week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[433]</a></sup> The ongoing <a href="/wiki/South%E2%80%93North_Water_Transfer_Project" title="South–North Water Transfer Project">South–North Water Transfer Project</a> intends to abate water shortage in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-forbes-454">[434]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_China" title="Demographics of China">Demographics of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PRC_Population_Density.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="857" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/PRC_Population_Density.svg/200px-PRC_Population_Density.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/PRC_Population_Density.svg/300px-PRC_Population_Density.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/PRC_Population_Density.svg/400px-PRC_Population_Density.svg.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PRC_Population_Density.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 2009 population density map of the People's Republic of China and Taiwan. The eastern coastal provinces are much more densely populated than the western interior</div></div></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px">
<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_21-2"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-21">[13]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Year
</th>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Million
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1950</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">554.4
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">2000</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">1283.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">2016</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">1403.5
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Sixth_National_Population_Census_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Sixth National Population Census of the People's Republic of China">national census of 2010</a> recorded the population of the People's Republic of China as approximately 1,370,536,875. About 16.60% of the population were 14 years old or younger, 70.14% were between 15 and 59 years old, and 13.26% were over 60 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[435]</a></sup> The population growth rate for 2013 is estimated to be 0.46%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although a middle-income country by Western standards, China's rapid growth has <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_China" title="Poverty in China">pulled hundreds of millions</a> of its people out of poverty since 1978. Today, about 10% of the Chinese population lives below the poverty line of US$1 per day, down from 64% in 1978. In 2014, the urban unemployment rate of China was about 4.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[438]</a></sup>
</p><p>Given concerns about population growth, China implemented a two-child limit during the 1970s, and, in 1979, began to advocate for an even stricter limit of one child per family.  Beginning in the mid 1980s, however, given the unpopularity of the strict limits, China began to allow some major exemptions, particularly in rural areas, resulting in what was actually a "1.5"-child policy from the mid 1980s to 2015 (ethnic minorities were also exempt from one child limits).  The next major loosening of the policy was enacted in December 2013, allowing families to have two children if one parent is an only child.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[439]</a></sup> In 2016, the one-child policy was replaced in favor of a <a href="/wiki/Two-child_policy" title="Two-child policy">two-child policy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[440]</a></sup> Data from the 2010 census implies that the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> may be around 1.4, although due to underreporting of births it may be closer to 1.5-1.6.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[441]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1240" data-file-width="1680" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg/200px-Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg/300px-Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg/400px-Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population of China from 1949 to 2008<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (October 2016)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup></div></div></div>
<p>According to one group of scholars, one-child limits had little effect on population growth<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wang_Judge_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wang_Judge-462">[442]</a></sup> or the size of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whyte_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-Whyte-463">[443]</a></sup> However, these scholars have been challenged.  Their own counterfactual model of fertility decline without such restrictions implies that China averted more than 500 million births between 1970 and 2015, a number which may reach one billion by 2060 given all the lost descendants of births averted during the era of fertility restrictions, with one-child restrictions accounting for the great bulk of that reduction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>The policy, along with traditional preference for boys, may have contributed to an imbalance in the <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">sex ratio</a> at birth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_2007a_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2007a-466">[446]</a></sup> According to the 2010 census, the sex ratio at birth was 118.06 boys for every 100 girls,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-genderratio_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-467">[447]</a></sup> which is beyond the normal range of around 105 boys for every 100 girls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[448]</a></sup> The 2010 census found that males accounted for 51.27 percent of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-genderratio_467-1"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-467">[447]</a></sup> However, China's sex ratio is more balanced than it was in 1953, when males accounted for 51.82 percent of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-genderratio_467-2"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-467">[447]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_China" title="List of ethnic groups in China">List of ethnic groups in China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_China" title="Ethnic minorities in China">Ethnic minorities in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Chinese_history" title="Ethnic groups in Chinese history">Ethnic groups in Chinese history</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Post_logo_with_(New)_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan,_Yunnan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="481" data-file-width="1616" height="65" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg/220px-China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg/330px-China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg/440px-China_Post_logo_with_%28New%29_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan%2C_Yunnan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Post_logo_with_(New)_Tai_L%C3%BC_script_in_Mohan,_Yunnan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A trilingual sign in <a href="/wiki/Xishuangbanna_Dai_Autonomous_Prefecture" title="Xishuangbanna Dai Autonomous Prefecture">Sibsongbanna</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tai_L%C3%BC_language" title="Tai Lü language">Tai Lü language</a> on the top</div></div></div>
<p>China officially recognizes 56 distinct ethnic groups, the largest of
which are the <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a>, who constitute about 91.51% of the total
population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-groups_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-groups-22">[14]</a></sup> The Han Chinese – the world's largest single ethnic group<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[449]</a></sup> – outnumber other ethnic groups in every provincial-level division except <a href="/wiki/Tibet_Autonomous_Region" title="Tibet Autonomous Region">Tibet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[450]</a></sup> Ethnic minorities account for about 8.49% of the population of China, according to
the 2010 census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-groups_22-2"><a href="#cite_note-groups-22">[14]</a></sup> Compared with the 2000 population census, the Han population increased by 66,537,177 persons, or 5.74%, while the population of the 55 national minorities combined increased by 7,362,627 persons, or 6.92%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-groups_22-3"><a href="#cite_note-groups-22">[14]</a></sup> The 2010 census recorded a total of 593,832 foreign citizens living in China. The largest such groups were from South Korea (120,750), the
United States (71,493) and Japan (66,159).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[451]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_China" title="Languages of China">Languages of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_China" title="List of endangered languages in China">List of endangered languages in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_linguistic_map.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2844" data-file-width="2538" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/China_linguistic_map.jpg/200px-China_linguistic_map.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/China_linguistic_map.jpg/300px-China_linguistic_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/China_linguistic_map.jpg/400px-China_linguistic_map.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_linguistic_map.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1990 map of Chinese ethnolinguistic groups</div></div></div>
<p>There are as many as 292 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Living_language" title="Living language">living languages</a> in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[452]</a></sup> The languages most commonly spoken belong to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinitic_languages" title="Sinitic languages">Sinitic branch</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sino-Tibetan_language" title="Sino-Tibetan language">Sino-Tibetan language</a> family, which contains <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Mandarin</a> (spoken by 70% of the population),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[453]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese" title="Varieties of Chinese">other varieties</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese language</a>: <a href="/wiki/Yue_Chinese" title="Yue Chinese">Yue</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taishanese" title="Taishanese">Taishanese</a>), <a href="/wiki/Wu_Chinese" title="Wu Chinese">Wu</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Shanghainese" title="Shanghainese">Shanghainese</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suzhounese" title="Suzhounese">Suzhounese</a>), <a href="/wiki/Min_Chinese" title="Min Chinese">Min</a> (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuzhounese" title="Fuzhounese">Fuzhounese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">Hokkien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Teochew_dialect" title="Teochew dialect">Teochew</a>), <a href="/wiki/Xiang_Chinese" title="Xiang Chinese">Xiang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gan_Chinese" title="Gan Chinese">Gan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hakka_language" title="Hakka language">Hakka</a>. Languages of the <a href="/wiki/Tibeto-Burman_languages" title="Tibeto-Burman languages">Tibeto-Burman branch</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Standard_Tibetan" title="Standard Tibetan">Tibetan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qiang_language" title="Qiang language">Qiang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naxi_language" title="Naxi language">Naxi</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yi_language" title="Yi language">Yi</a>, are spoken across the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Plateau" title="Tibetan Plateau">Tibetan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yunnan%E2%80%93Guizhou_Plateau" title="Yunnan–Guizhou Plateau">Yunnan–Guizhou Plateau</a>. Other ethnic minority languages in <a href="/wiki/Southwest_China" title="Southwest China">southwest China</a> include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhuang_language" title="Zhuang language">Zhuang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_language" title="Thai language">Thai</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dong_language" title="Dong language">Dong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sui_language" title="Sui language">Sui</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tai%E2%80%93Kadai_languages" title="Tai–Kadai languages">Tai-Kadai family</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hmongic_language" title="Hmongic language">Miao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mienic_languages" title="Mienic languages">Yao</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Hmong%E2%80%93Mien_languages" title="Hmong–Mien languages">Hmong–Mien family</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wa_language" title="Wa language">Wa</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_Languages" title="Austroasiatic Languages">Austroasiatic family</a>. Across <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeastern_China" title="Northeastern China">northeastern</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northwestern_China" title="Northwestern China">northwestern China</a>, local ethnic groups speak <a href="/wiki/Altaic_languages" title="Altaic languages">Altaic languages</a> including <a href="/wiki/Manchu_language" title="Manchu language">Manchu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_language" title="Mongolian language">Mongolian</a> and several <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a>: <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_language" title="Uyghur language">Uyghur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakh_language" title="Kazakh language">Kazakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyz_language" title="Kyrgyz language">Kyrgyz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salar_language" title="Salar language">Salar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Yugur_language" title="Western Yugur language">Western Yugur</a>. <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a> is spoken natively along the border with <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. <a href="/wiki/Sarikoli_language" title="Sarikoli language">Sarikoli</a>, the language of <a href="/wiki/Tajiks_of_Xinjiang" title="Tajiks of Xinjiang">Tajiks in western Xinjiang</a>, is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanese_aborigines" title="Taiwanese aborigines">Taiwanese aborigines</a>, including a small population on the mainland, speak <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-language_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-language-474">[454]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_Mandarin" title="Standard Mandarin">Standard Mandarin</a>, a variety of Mandarin based on the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_dialect" title="Beijing dialect">Beijing dialect</a>, is the official national language of China and is used as a <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> in the country between people of different linguistic backgrounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[455]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a> have been used as the <a href="/wiki/Writing_system" title="Writing system">written script</a> for the Sinitic languages for thousands of years. They allow speakers of mutually unintelligible Chinese varieties to communicate with each other through writing. In 1956, the government introduced <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified characters</a>, which have supplanted the older <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional characters</a> in mainland China. Chinese characters are <a href="/wiki/Romanization" title="Romanization">romanized</a> using the <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">Pinyin system</a>. Tibetan uses an <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_alphabet" title="Tibetan alphabet">alphabet</a> based on an <a href="/wiki/Brahmic_scripts" title="Brahmic scripts">Indic script</a>. Uyghur is most commonly written in <a href="/wiki/Persian_alphabet" title="Persian alphabet">Persian alphabet</a> based <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_Arabic_alphabet" title="Uyghur Arabic alphabet">Uyghur Arabic alphabet</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_script" title="Mongolian script">Mongolian script used in China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Manchu_alphabet" title="Manchu alphabet">Manchu script</a> are both derived from the <a href="/wiki/Old_Uyghur_alphabet" title="Old Uyghur alphabet">Old Uyghur alphabet</a>. <a href="/wiki/Zhuang_languages" title="Zhuang languages">Zhuang</a> uses both an official <a href="/wiki/Standard_Zhuang" title="Standard Zhuang">Latin alphabet script</a> and a traditional <a href="/wiki/Sawndip" title="Sawndip">Chinese character script</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China" title="List of cities in China">List of cities in China</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">List of cities in China by population</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_regions_of_China" title="Metropolitan regions of China">Metropolitan regions of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="930" data-file-width="1058" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png/200px-China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png/300px-China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png/400px-China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Top_10_Biggest_Cities.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the ten <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">largest cities</a> in China (2010)</div></div></div>
<p>China has urbanized significantly in recent decades. The percent of the country's population living in urban areas increased from 20% in 1980 to over 55% in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[456]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-477">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinasUrbanFuture_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinasUrbanFuture-478">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Data_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-National_Data-479">[459]</a></sup> It is estimated that China's urban population will reach one billion by 2030, potentially equivalent to one-eighth of the world population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_477-1"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-477">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinasUrbanFuture_478-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChinasUrbanFuture-478">[458]</a></sup> As of  2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are more than 262 million <a href="/wiki/Migrant_worker" title="Migrant worker">migrant workers</a> in China, mostly rural migrants seeking work in cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[460]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has over 160 cities with a population of over one million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[461]</a></sup> including the seven <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacities</a> (cities with a population of over 10 million) of Chongqing, Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou, Tianjin, Shenzhen, and Wuhan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[464]</a></sup> By 2025, it is estimated that the country will be home to 221 cities with over a million inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_477-2"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-477">[457]</a></sup> The figures in the table below are from the 2010 census,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-census-7">[4]</a></sup> and are only estimates of the urban populations within administrative city limits; a different ranking exists when considering the total municipal populations (which includes suburban and rural populations). The large "<a href="/wiki/Floating_population" title="Floating population">floating populations</a>" of migrant workers make conducting censuses in urban areas difficult;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abce_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abce-485">[465]</a></sup> the figures below include only long-term residents.
</p>
<table class="navbox">
<tbody><tr>
