<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Education_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Education in the People's Republic of China">Education in the People's Republic of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_China" title="List of universities in China">List of universities in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2_Tsinghua.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/2_Tsinghua.jpg/220px-2_Tsinghua.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/2_Tsinghua.jpg/330px-2_Tsinghua.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/2_Tsinghua.jpg/440px-2_Tsinghua.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2_Tsinghua.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_university_ranking_(Wu_Shulian)" title="Chinese university ranking (Wu Shulian)">top-ranked universities in China</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[466]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since 1986, compulsory education in China comprises <a href="/wiki/Primary_school" title="Primary school">primary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">junior secondary school</a>, which together last for nine years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[467]</a></sup> In 2010, about 82.5 percent of students continued their education at a three-year senior secondary school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[468]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaokao" title="Gaokao">Gaokao</a>, China's national university entrance exam, is a prerequisite for entrance into most higher education institutions. In 2010, 27 percent of secondary school graduates are enrolled in higher education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[469]</a></sup> This number increased significantly over the last years, reaching a tertiary school enrollment of 48.4 percent in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[470]</a></sup> Vocational education is available to students at the secondary and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary</a> level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[471]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2006, the government pledged to provide completely free nine-year education, including textbooks and fees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abch_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abch-492">[472]</a></sup> Annual education investment went from less than US$50 billion in 2003 to more than US$250 billion in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[473]</a></sup> However, there remains an inequality in education spending. In 2010, the annual education expenditure per secondary school student in Beijing totalled ¥20,023, while in <a href="/wiki/Guizhou" title="Guizhou">Guizhou</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP_per_capita" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP per capita">poorest provinces in China</a>, only totalled ¥3,204.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[474]</a></sup> Free compulsory education in China consists of primary school and junior secondary school between the ages of 6 and 15. In 2011, around 81.4% of Chinese have received secondary education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[475]</a></sup> By 2007, there were 396,567 primary schools, 94,116 secondary schools, and 2,236 higher education institutions in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[476]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of  2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 94% of the population over age 15 are literate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[477]</a></sup> In 1949, only 20% of the population could read, compared to 65.5% thirty years later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[478]</a></sup> In 2009, Chinese students from Shanghai achieved the world's best results in mathematics, science and literacy, as tested by the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> (PISA), a worldwide evaluation of 15-year-old school pupils' scholastic performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[479]</a></sup> Despite the high results, Chinese education has also faced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criticism_of_education_in_China" title="Criticism of education in China">both native and international criticism</a> for its emphasis on rote memorization and its gap in quality from rural to urban areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[480]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_China" title="Health in China">Health in China</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_China" title="Pharmaceutical industry in China">Pharmaceutical industry in China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="295" data-file-width="438" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg/200px-China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg/300px-China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg/400px-China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chart showing the rise of China's <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> from 1970 to 2010</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Health_and_Family_Planning_Commission" title="National Health and Family Planning Commission">National Health and Family Planning Commission</a>, together with its counterparts in the local commissions, oversees the health needs of the Chinese population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[481]</a></sup> An emphasis on public health and preventive medicine has characterized Chinese health policy since the early 1950s. At that time, the Communist Party started the <a href="/wiki/Patriotic_Health_Campaign" title="Patriotic Health Campaign">Patriotic Health Campaign</a>, which was aimed at improving sanitation and hygiene, as well as treating and preventing several diseases. Diseases such as <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Typhoid" title="Typhoid">typhoid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_fever" title="Scarlet fever">scarlet fever</a>, which were previously rife in China, were nearly eradicated by the campaign. After Deng Xiaoping began instituting economic reforms in 1978, the health of the Chinese public improved rapidly because of better nutrition, although many of the free public health services provided in the countryside disappeared along with the People's Communes. Healthcare in China became mostly <a href="/wiki/Private_healthcare" title="Private healthcare">privatized</a>, and experienced a significant rise in quality. In 2009, the government began a 3-year large-scale healthcare provision initiative worth US$124 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[482]</a></sup> By 2011, the campaign resulted in 95% of China's population having basic health insurance coverage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[483]</a></sup> In 2011, China was estimated to be the world's third-largest supplier of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, but its population has suffered from the development and distribution of <a href="/wiki/Counterfeit_medications" title="Counterfeit medications">counterfeit medications</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[484]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of  2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the average life expectancy at birth in China is 75 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[485]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate is 12 per thousand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[486]</a></sup> Both have improved significantly since the 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[u]</a></sup> Rates of <a href="/wiki/Stunted_growth" title="Stunted growth">stunting</a>, a condition caused by <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>, have declined from 33.1% in 1990 to 9.9% in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[489]</a></sup> Despite significant improvements in health and the construction of advanced medical facilities, China has several emerging public health problems, such as respiratory illnesses caused by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_China" title="Air pollution in China">widespread air pollution</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT-china-pollution_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-FT-china-pollution-511">[490]</a></sup> hundreds of millions of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco_smoking" title="Tobacco smoking">cigarette smokers</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcx_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcx-512">[491]</a></sup> and an increase in <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a> among urban youths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcy_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcy-513">[492]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcz_514-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcz-514">[493]</a></sup> China's large population and densely populated cities have led to serious disease outbreaks in recent years, such as the 2003 outbreak of <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome">SARS</a>, although this has since been largely contained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcda_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcda-515">[494]</a></sup> In 2010, air pollution caused 1.2 million premature deaths in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[495]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_China" title="Religion in China">Religion in China</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">Freedom of religion</a> is guaranteed by China's constitution, although religious organizations that lack official approval can be subject to state persecution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XinBan2012_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-XinBan2012-273">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[496]</a></sup> The government of the People's Republic of China is officially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">atheist</a>. Religious affairs and issues in the country are overseen by the <a href="/wiki/State_Administration_for_Religious_Affairs" title="State Administration for Religious Affairs">State Administration for Religious Affairs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[497]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the millennia, Chinese civilization has been influenced by various religious movements. The "<a href="/wiki/Three_teachings" title="Three teachings">three teachings</a>", including <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">Chinese Buddhism</a>), historically have a significant role in shaping Chinese culture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yao2011_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yao2011-519">[498]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[499]</a></sup> enriching a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_theology" title="Chinese theology">theological and spiritual framework</a> which harkens back to the early <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou dynasty</a>. Chinese popular or folk religion, which is framed by the three teachings and other traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[500]</a></sup> consists in allegiance to the <i><a href="/wiki/Shen_(Chinese_religion)" title="Shen (Chinese religion)">shen</a></i> (神), a character that signifies the "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_gods_and_immortals" title="Chinese gods and immortals">energies of generation</a>", who can be <a href="/wiki/Deity" title="Deity">deities</a> of the environment or <a href="/wiki/Progenitor" title="Progenitor">ancestral principles</a> of human groups, concepts of civility, <a href="/wiki/Culture_hero" title="Culture hero">culture heroes</a>, many of whom feature in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_mythology" title="Chinese mythology">Chinese mythology</a> and history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[501]</a></sup> Among the most popular <a href="/wiki/Cult_(religious_practice)" title="Cult (religious practice)">cults</a> are those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mazu_(goddess)" title="Mazu (goddess)">Mazu</a> (goddess of the seas),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laliberte2011_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-Laliberte2011-523">[502]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Emperor" title="Yellow Emperor">Huangdi</a> (one of the two <a href="/wiki/Yan_Huang_Zisun" title="Yan Huang Zisun">divine patriarchs</a> of the Chinese race),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laliberte2011_523-1"><a href="#cite_note-Laliberte2011-523">[502]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[503]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guandi" title="Guandi">Guandi</a> (god of war and business), <a href="/wiki/Caishen" title="Caishen">Caishen</a> (god of prosperity and richness), <a href="/wiki/Pangu" title="Pangu">Pangu</a> and many others. China is home to many of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_statues_by_height" title="List of statues by height">world's tallest religious statues</a>, including the tallest of all, the <a href="/wiki/Spring_Temple_Buddha" title="Spring Temple Buddha">Spring Temple Buddha</a> in <a href="/wiki/Henan" title="Henan">Henan</a>.
</p><p>Clear data on religious affiliation in China is difficult to gather due to varying definitions on "religion" and the unorganized, diffusive nature of Chinese religious traditions. Scholars note that in China there is no clear boundary between <a href="/wiki/Three_teachings" title="Three teachings">three teachings</a> religions, Buddhism, Taoism and local folk religious practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yao2011_519-1"><a href="#cite_note-Yao2011-519">[498]</a></sup> A 2015 poll conducted by <a href="/wiki/WIN/GIA" title="WIN/GIA">Gallup International</a> found that 61% of Chinese people self-identified as "convinced atheist",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GallupInternational_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-GallupInternational-525">[504]</a></sup> though it is worthwhile to note that Chinese religions or some of their strands are definable as <a href="/wiki/Nontheism" title="Nontheism">non-theistic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Humanistic" title="Humanistic">humanistic</a> religions, since they do not believe that divine creativity is completely transcendent, but it is inherent in the world and in particular in the human being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[505]</a></sup> According to a 2014 study, approximately 74% are either non-religious or practise Chinese folk belief, 16% are Buddhists, 2% are Christians, 1% are Muslims, and 8% adhere to other religions including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taoists" title="Taoists">Taoists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_salvationist_religions" title="Chinese salvationist religions">folk salvationism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CFPS2014_527-0"><a href="#cite_note-CFPS2014-527">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CZ20172_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-CZ20172-528">[507]</a></sup> In addition to Han people's local religious practices, there are also various <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_China" title="Ethnic minorities in China">ethnic minority groups in China</a> who maintain their <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_China#Ethnic_minorities'_indigenous_religions" title="Religion in China">traditional autochthone religions</a>. The various folk salvationisms today comprise 2–3% of the population, while Confucianism as a religious self-identification is common within the intellectual class. Significant faiths specifically connected to certain ethnic groups include <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Islamic religion</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Hui_people" title="Hui people">Hui people</a>, also of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uyghur_people" title="Uyghur people">Uyghur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhs_in_China" title="Kazakhs in China">Kazakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyz_in_China" title="Kyrgyz in China">Kyrgyz</a> and other peoples in the Northwest China.
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px"><div style="width: 182.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_temple_in_Midong,_Urumqi,_Xinjiang_(2).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="3216" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Buddhist_temple_in_Midong%2C_Urumqi%2C_Xinjiang_%282%29.jpg/271px-Buddhist_temple_in_Midong%2C_Urumqi%2C_Xinjiang_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Buddhist_temple_in_Midong%2C_Urumqi%2C_Xinjiang_%282%29.jpg/407px-Buddhist_temple_in_Midong%2C_Urumqi%2C_Xinjiang_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Buddhist_temple_in_Midong%2C_Urumqi%2C_Xinjiang_%282%29.jpg/542px-Buddhist_temple_in_Midong%2C_Urumqi%2C_Xinjiang_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="181"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Temple of the Great Buddha in <a href="/wiki/Midong_District" title="Midong District">Midong</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urumqi" title="Urumqi">Urumqi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>. China has many of the tallest statues in the world, and most of them represent deities and buddhas.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg/240px-The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg/360px-The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg/480px-The_yard_leading_to_The_White_Sulde_Temple.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Temple of the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BClde_Tngri" title="Sülde Tngri">White Sulde</a> of <a href="/wiki/Genghis_Khan" title="Genghis Khan">Genghis Khan</a> in the town of <a href="/wiki/Uxin_Banner" title="Uxin Banner">Uxin</a> in <a href="/wiki/Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia">Inner Mongolia</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Ordos_Desert" title="Ordos Desert">Mu Us Desert</a>. <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Inner_Mongolia" title="Religion in Inner Mongolia">Religion in Inner Mongolia</a> blends Chinese and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongolian_folk_religious" title="Mongolian folk religious">Mongolian folk religious</a> traditions.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px"><div style="width: 182px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an,_Shaanxi.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1068" data-file-width="1600" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an%2C_Shaanxi.jpg/270px-Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an%2C_Shaanxi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an%2C_Shaanxi.jpg/405px-Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an%2C_Shaanxi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an%2C_Shaanxi.jpg/540px-Xuanyuan_Temple_in_Yan%27an%2C_Shaanxi.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xuanyuan_Temple" title="Xuanyuan Temple">Xuanyuan Temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Huangling_County" title="Huangling County">Huangling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yan%27an" title="Yan'an">Yan'an</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaanxi" title="Shaanxi">Shaanxi</a>, dedicated to the worship of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Emperor" title="Yellow Emperor">Yellow Emperor</a> (said to be the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Descendants_of_Yan_and_Huang" title="Descendants of Yan and Huang">ancestor of all Chinese</a>) at the ideal sacred centre of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[v]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px"><div style="width: 182.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4912" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG/271px-The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG/407px-The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG/542px-The_Temple_of_Lord_Guan_in_Chaoyang_27_2015-09.JPG 2x" width="181"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Temple of Guandi in <a href="/wiki/Chaoyang,_Liaoning" title="Chaoyang, Liaoning">Chaoyang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liaoning" title="Liaoning">Liaoning</a>. <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Northeast_China" title="Religion in Northeast China">Religion in Northeast China</a> is characterised by the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_China_folk_religion" title="Northeast China folk religion">interaction of folk religions</a> of Chinese and Manchus (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manchu_folk_religion" title="Manchu folk religion">Manchu folk religion</a>). Confucian religious movements like <a href="/wiki/Shanrendao" title="Shanrendao">Shanrendao</a> are widespread.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px"><div style="width: 182.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="680" data-file-width="1024" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg/271px-Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg/407px-Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg/542px-Taoists_performing_a_rite_at_the_Baiyun_Temple_of_Shanghai.jpg 2x" width="181"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Taoist_priest" title="Taoist priest">Taoist priests</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhengyi_Taoism" title="Zhengyi Taoism">Zhengyi order</a> bowing during a rite at the White Cloud Temple of <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>. Taoism is a set of <a href="/wiki/Taoist_schools" title="Taoist schools">orders of philosophy and rite</a> that operate as frameworks of Chinese religion, alongside <a href="/wiki/Chinese_ritual_mastery_traditions" title="Chinese ritual mastery traditions">vernacular ritual traditions</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 293.33333333333px"><div style="width: 293.33333333333px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 291.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1_Seda_facing_south.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="6888" data-file-width="16716" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/1_Seda_facing_south.jpg/437px-1_Seda_facing_south.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/1_Seda_facing_south.jpg/656px-1_Seda_facing_south.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/1_Seda_facing_south.jpg/874px-1_Seda_facing_south.jpg 2x" width="292"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Larung_Gar_Buddhist_Academy" title="Larung Gar Buddhist Academy">Larung Gar Academy</a> of Tibetan Buddhism in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%AArtar_County" title="Sêrtar County">Sêrtar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garz%C3%AA_Tibetan_Autonomous_Prefecture" title="Garzê Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture">Garzê</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a>. Founded in the 1980s, it is now the largest monastic institution in the world, with about 40,000 members of which 1/10 are <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_(%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E),_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_(%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99)_in_Hebi_(%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82),_Henan,_China.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_%28%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E%29%2C_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_%28%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99%29_in_Hebi_%28%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82%29%2C_Henan%2C_China.jpg/240px-Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_%28%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E%29%2C_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_%28%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99%29_in_Hebi_%28%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82%29%2C_Henan%2C_China.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_%28%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E%29%2C_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_%28%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99%29_in_Hebi_%28%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82%29%2C_Henan%2C_China.jpg/360px-Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_%28%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E%29%2C_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_%28%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99%29_in_Hebi_%28%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82%29%2C_Henan%2C_China.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_%28%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E%29%2C_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_%28%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99%29_in_Hebi_%28%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82%29%2C_Henan%2C_China.jpg/480px-Main_temple_of_the_City_of_the_Eight_Symbols_%28%E5%85%AB%E5%8D%A6%E5%9F%8E%29%2C_the_holy_see_of_Weixinism_%28%E5%94%AF%E5%BF%83%E6%95%99%29_in_Hebi_%28%E9%B9%A4%E5%A3%81%E5%B8%82%29%2C_Henan%2C_China.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The City of the Eight Symbols in <a href="/wiki/Qi_County,_Hebi" title="Qi County, Hebi">Qi County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebi" title="Hebi">Hebi</a>, is the headquarters of the Weixinist Church in <a href="/wiki/Henan" title="Henan">Henan</a>. <a href="/wiki/Weixinism" title="Weixinism">Weixinism</a> is a 21st-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_salvationist_religion" title="Chinese salvationist religion">renewal movement</a> of Chinese religion and philosophy.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px"><div style="width: 182.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2368" data-file-width="3568" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg/271px-The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg/407px-The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg/543px-The_Temple_of_the_Town_Deity_in_Sheng_County_44_2017-03.jpg 2x" width="181"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Temple of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_God_(East_Asia)" title="City God (East Asia)">City God</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sheng_County" title="Sheng County">Sheng County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang" title="Zhejiang">Zhejiang</a>. City Gods are tutelary deities of administrative units whose worship became common by the late <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a>. Generally, they are deified historical persons from that given locality who distinguished themselves through extraordinary attainments.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 191.33333333333px"><div style="width: 191.33333333333px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 189.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou,_Guangxi.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="618" data-file-width="974" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou%2C_Guangxi.jpg/284px-%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou%2C_Guangxi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou%2C_Guangxi.jpg/426px-%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou%2C_Guangxi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou%2C_Guangxi.jpg/568px-%E6%9F%B3%E5%B7%9E%E5%B8%82%E5%AD%94%E5%BA%99_Temple_of_Confucius_in_Liuzhou%2C_Guangxi.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Temple of the Culture Deity (<a href="/wiki/Confucius" title="Confucius">Confucius</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Liuzhou" title="Liuzhou">Liuzhou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a>. Confucius is widely worshipped as the Culture Deity in popular religion. Confucianism as a religion is practised by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confucian_churches" title="Confucian churches">Confucian churches</a>, for instance the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Confucian_Church" title="Holy Confucian Church">Holy Confucian Church</a> established in 2009 in <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>.
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Culture of the People's Republic of China">Culture of the People's Republic of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2432" data-file-width="3648" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg/220px-11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg/330px-11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg/440px-11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:11_Temple_of_Heaven.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Heaven" title="Temple of Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a>, a center of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heaven_worship" title="Heaven worship">heaven worship</a> and an UNESCO World Heritage site, symbolizes the <a href="/wiki/Interactions_Between_Heaven_and_Mankind" title="Interactions Between Heaven and Mankind">Interactions Between Heaven and Mankind</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[509]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since ancient times, Chinese culture has been heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> and conservative philosophies. For much of the country's dynastic era, opportunities for social advancement could be provided by high performance in the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Imperial_examination" title="Imperial examination">imperial examinations</a>, which have their origins in the <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[510]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">literary emphasis</a> of the exams affected the general perception of cultural refinement in China, such as the belief that <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calligraphy" title="Chinese calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese_poetry" title="Classical Chinese poetry">poetry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_painting" title="Chinese painting">painting</a> were higher forms of art than dancing or drama. Chinese culture has long emphasized a sense of deep history and a largely inward-looking national perspective.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_40-2"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-40">[29]</a></sup> Examinations and a <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">culture of merit</a> remain greatly valued in China today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[511]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Youyicun_garden.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1418" data-file-width="1873" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Youyicun_garden.jpg/220px-Youyicun_garden.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Youyicun_garden.jpg/330px-Youyicun_garden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Youyicun_garden.jpg/440px-Youyicun_garden.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Youyicun_garden.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Classical_Gardens_of_Suzhou" title="Classical Gardens of Suzhou">Classical Gardens of Suzhou</a></div></div></div>
<p>The first leaders of the People's Republic of China were born into the traditional imperial order, but were influenced by the <a href="/wiki/May_Fourth_Movement" title="May Fourth Movement">May Fourth Movement</a> and reformist ideals. They sought to change some traditional aspects of Chinese culture, such as rural land tenure, <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexism</a>, and the Confucian system of education, while preserving others, such as the family structure and culture of obedience to the state. Some observers see the period following the establishment of the PRC in 1949 as a continuation of traditional Chinese dynastic history, while others claim that the Communist Party's rule has damaged the foundations of Chinese culture, especially through political movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> of the 1960s, where many aspects of traditional culture were destroyed, having been denounced as "regressive and harmful" or "vestiges of <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>". Many important aspects of traditional Chinese morals and culture, such as Confucianism, art, literature, and performing arts like <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcded_534-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcded-534">[512]</a></sup> were altered to conform to government policies and propaganda at the time. Access to foreign media remains heavily restricted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[513]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, the Chinese government has accepted numerous elements of traditional Chinese culture as being integral to Chinese society. With the rise of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_nationalism" title="Chinese nationalism">Chinese nationalism</a> and the end of the Cultural Revolution, various forms of traditional Chinese art, literature, music, film, fashion and architecture have seen a vigorous revival,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdef_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdef-536">[514]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeg_537-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeg-537">[515]</a></sup> and folk and variety art in particular have sparked interest nationally and even worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeh_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeh-538">[516]</a></sup> China is now the <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_China" title="Tourism in China">third-most-visited country in the world</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[517]</a></sup> with 55.7 million inbound international visitors in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abd_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abd-540">[518]</a></sup> It also experiences an enormous volume of <a href="/wiki/Domestic_tourism" title="Domestic tourism">domestic tourism</a>; an estimated 740 million Chinese holidaymakers travelled within the country in October 2012 alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-740MillionTourists_541-0"><a href="#cite_note-740MillionTourists-541">[519]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">Chinese literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG/200px-Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG/300px-Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG/400px-Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pekin_przedstawienie_tradycjnego_teatru_chinskiego_7.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The stories in <i><a href="/wiki/Journey_to_the_West" title="Journey to the West">Journey to the West</a></i> are common themes in <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Chinese literature is based on the literature of the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[520]</a></sup> Concepts covered within the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_classic_texts" title="Chinese classic texts">Chinese classic texts</a> present a wide range of <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Schools_of_Thought" title="Hundred Schools of Thought">thoughts</a> and subjects including <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calendar" title="Chinese calendar">calendar</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_military_texts" title="List of Chinese military texts">military</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_astrology" title="Chinese astrology">astrology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_herbology" title="Chinese herbology">herbology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_geography" title="Chinese geography">geography</a> and many others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[521]</a></sup> Some of the most important early texts include the <i><a href="/wiki/I_Ching" title="I Ching">I Ching</a></i> and the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classic_of_History" title="Classic of History">Shujing</a></i> within the <a href="/wiki/Four_Books_and_Five_Classics" title="Four Books and Five Classics">Four Books and Five Classics</a> which served as the Confucian authoritative books for the state-sponsored curriculum in dynastic era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[522]</a></sup> Inherited from the <i><a href="/wiki/Classic_of_Poetry" title="Classic of Poetry">Classic of Poetry</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese_poetry" title="Classical Chinese poetry">classical Chinese poetry</a> developed to its floruit during the Tang dynasty. <a href="/wiki/Li_Bai" title="Li Bai">Li Bai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Du_Fu" title="Du Fu">Du Fu</a> opened the forking ways for the poetic circles through romanticism and realism respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[523]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_historiography" title="Chinese historiography">Chinese historiography</a> began with the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shiji" title="Shiji">Shiji</a></i>, the overall scope of the historiographical tradition in China is termed the <a href="/wiki/Twenty-Four_Histories" title="Twenty-Four Histories">Twenty-Four Histories</a>, which set a vast stage for Chinese fictions along with <a href="/wiki/Chinese_mythology" title="Chinese mythology">Chinese mythology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folklore" title="Chinese folklore">folklore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[524]</a></sup> Pushed by a burgeoning citizen class in the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>, Chinese classical fiction rose to a boom of the historical, town and <a href="/wiki/Gods_and_demons_fiction" title="Gods and demons fiction">gods and demons fictions</a> as represented by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_Great_Classical_Novels" title="Four Great Classical Novels">Four Great Classical Novels</a> which include <i><a href="/wiki/Water_Margin" title="Water Margin">Water Margin</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Romance of the Three Kingdoms">Romance of the Three Kingdoms</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Journey_to_the_West" title="Journey to the West">Journey to the West</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dream_of_the_Red_Chamber" title="Dream of the Red Chamber">Dream of the Red Chamber</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[525]</a></sup> Along with the <a href="/wiki/Wuxia" title="Wuxia">wuxia</a> fictions of <a href="/wiki/Jin_Yong" title="Jin Yong">Jin Yong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liang_Yusheng" title="Liang Yusheng">Liang Yusheng</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[526]</a></sup> it remains an enduring source of popular culture in the <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_cultural_sphere" title="East Asian cultural sphere">East Asian cultural sphere</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[527]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bianlian.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1644" data-file-width="2302" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bianlian.JPG/220px-Bianlian.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bianlian.JPG/330px-Bianlian.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bianlian.JPG/440px-Bianlian.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bianlian.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bian_Lian" title="Bian Lian">Bian Lian</a> (Face-Changing) Performer</div></div></div>
<p>In the wake of the <a href="/wiki/New_Culture_Movement" title="New Culture Movement">New Culture Movement</a> after the end of the Qing dynasty, Chinese literature embarked on a new era with <a href="/wiki/Written_vernacular_Chinese" title="Written vernacular Chinese">written vernacular Chinese</a> for ordinary citizens. <a href="/wiki/Hu_Shih" title="Hu Shih">Hu Shih</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lu_Xun" title="Lu Xun">Lu Xun</a> were pioneers in modern literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[528]</a></sup> Various literary genres, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Misty_poetry" title="Misty poetry">misty poetry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scar_literature" title="Scar literature">scar literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Young_adult_fiction" title="Young adult fiction">young adult fiction</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Xungen_movement" title="Xungen movement">xungen literature</a>, which is influenced by <a href="/wiki/Magic_realism" title="Magic realism">magic realism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[529]</a></sup> emerged following the Cultural Revolution. <a href="/wiki/Mo_Yan" title="Mo Yan">Mo Yan</a>, a xungen literature author, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[530]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">Chinese cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="450" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg/200px-Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg/300px-Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg/400px-Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_foods_from_different_regional_cuisines.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Foods from different regional cuisines: <a href="/wiki/Laziji" title="Laziji">laziji</a> from Sichuan cuisine; <a href="/wiki/Xiaolongbao" title="Xiaolongbao">xiaolongbao</a> from Jiangsu cuisine; <a href="/wiki/Rice_noodle_roll" title="Rice noodle roll">rice noodle roll</a> from Cantonese cuisine; and <a href="/wiki/Peking_duck" title="Peking duck">Peking duck</a> from Shandong cuisine<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[531]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Chinese cuisine is highly diverse, drawing on several millennia of culinary history and geographical variety, in which the most influential are known as the "Eight Major Cuisines", including <a href="/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine" title="Sichuan cuisine">Sichuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine" title="Cantonese cuisine">Cantonese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiangsu_cuisine" title="Jiangsu cuisine">Jiangsu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shandong_cuisine" title="Shandong cuisine">Shandong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fujian_cuisine" title="Fujian cuisine">Fujian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunan_cuisine" title="Hunan cuisine">Hunan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anhui_cuisine" title="Anhui cuisine">Anhui</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang_cuisine" title="Zhejiang cuisine">Zhejiang</a> cuisines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[532]</a></sup> All of them are featured by the precise skills of shaping, heating, colorway and flavoring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[533]</a></sup> Chinese cuisine is also known for its width of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cooking_techniques" title="Chinese cooking techniques">cooking methods</a> and ingredients,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[534]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Chinese_food_therapy" title="Chinese food therapy">food therapy</a> that is emphasized by <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine">traditional Chinese medicine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[535]</a></sup> Generally, China's staple food is rice in the south, wheat based breads and noodles in the north. The diet of the common people in pre-modern times was largely grain and simple vegetables, with meat reserved for special occasions. And the bean products, such as <a href="/wiki/Tofu" title="Tofu">tofu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, remain as a popular source of protein.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[536]</a></sup> Pork is now the most popular meat in China, accounting for about three-fourths of the country's total meat consumption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[537]</a></sup> While pork dominates the meat market, there is also pork-free <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cuisine" title="Buddhist cuisine">Buddhist cuisine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Islamic_cuisine" title="Chinese Islamic cuisine">Chinese Islamic cuisine</a>. Southern cuisine, due to the area's proximity to the ocean and milder climate, has a wide variety of seafood and vegetables; it differs in many respects from the wheat-based diets across dry northern China. Numerous offshoots of Chinese food, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_Hong_Kong#Eastern_Styles" title="Cuisine of Hong Kong">Hong Kong cuisine</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Chinese_food" title="American Chinese food">American Chinese food</a>, have emerged in the nations that play host to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_diaspora" title="Chinese diaspora">Chinese diaspora</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_China" title="Sport in China">Sport in China</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_at_the_Olympics" title="China at the Olympics">China at the Olympics</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_boat_racing.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1572" data-file-width="2092" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Dragon_boat_racing.jpg/200px-Dragon_boat_racing.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Dragon_boat_racing.jpg/300px-Dragon_boat_racing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Dragon_boat_racing.jpg/400px-Dragon_boat_racing.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_boat_racing.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dragon_boat" title="Dragon boat">Dragon boat</a> racing, a popular traditional Chinese sport</div></div></div>
<p>China has become a prime sports destination worldwide. The country gained the hosting rights for several major global sports tournaments including the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2015_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2015 World Championships in Athletics">2015 World Championships in Athletics</a>, the upcoming <a href="/wiki/2019_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup" title="2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup">2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup</a> and the upcoming <a href="/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics" title="2022 Winter Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>.
</p><p>China has one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Sport in the People's Republic of China">oldest sporting cultures</a> in the world. There is evidence that archery (<i>shèjiàn</i>) was practiced during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Zhou_dynasty" title="Western Zhou dynasty">Western Zhou dynasty</a>. Swordplay (<i>jiànshù</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Cuju" title="Cuju">cuju</a>, a sport loosely related to <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[538]</a></sup> date back to China's early dynasties as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[539]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Echecs_chinois.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Echecs_chinois.JPG/220px-Echecs_chinois.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Echecs_chinois.JPG/330px-Echecs_chinois.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Echecs_chinois.JPG/440px-Echecs_chinois.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Echecs_chinois.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Xiangqi" title="Xiangqi">Xiangqi</a>, or Chinese chess, which, like <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Western Chess</a> is believed to be descended from the <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">Indian</a> chess game of <a href="/wiki/Chaturanga" title="Chaturanga">chaturanga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[540]</a></sup>  The earliest indications reveal the game may have been played as early as the third century BCE.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Physical_fitness" title="Physical fitness">Physical fitness</a> is widely emphasized in Chinese culture, with morning exercises such as <a href="/wiki/Qigong" title="Qigong">qigong</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%27ai_chi_ch%27uan" title="T'ai chi ch'uan">t'ai chi ch'uan</a> widely practiced,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[541]</a></sup> and commercial <a href="/wiki/Gym" title="Gym">gyms</a> and private fitness clubs are gaining popularity across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[542]</a></sup> Basketball is currently the most popular spectator sport in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[543]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Basketball_Association" title="Chinese Basketball Association">Chinese Basketball Association</a> and the American <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a> have a huge following among the people, with native or ethnic Chinese players such as <a href="/wiki/Yao_Ming" title="Yao Ming">Yao Ming</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yi_Jianlian" title="Yi Jianlian">Yi Jianlian</a> held in high esteem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beech2003_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beech2003-566">[544]</a></sup> China's professional football league, now known as <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Super_League" title="Chinese Super League">Chinese Super League</a>, was established in 1994, it is the largest football market in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[545]</a></sup> Other popular sports in the country include <a href="/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts" title="Chinese martial arts">martial arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swimming" title="Swimming">swimming</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">snooker</a>. <a href="/wiki/Board_game" title="Board game">Board games</a> such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Go_(board_game)" title="Go (board game)">go</a> (known as <i>wéiqí</i> in Chinese), <a href="/wiki/Xiangqi" title="Xiangqi">xiangqi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahjong" title="Mahjong">mahjong</a>, and more recently <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a>, are also played at a professional level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[546]</a></sup> In addition, China is home to a huge number of <a href="/wiki/Cycling" title="Cycling">cyclists</a>, with an estimated 470 million bicycles as of  2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=China&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470MBikes_436-1"><a href="#cite_note-470MBikes-436">[416]</a></sup> Many more traditional sports, such as <a href="/wiki/Dragon_boat" title="Dragon boat">dragon boat</a> racing, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_wrestling" title="Mongolian wrestling">Mongolian-style wrestling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a> are also popular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcden_569-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcden-569">[547]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has <a href="/wiki/China_at_the_Olympics" title="China at the Olympics">participated in the Olympic Games</a> since 1932, although it has only participated as the PRC <a href="/wiki/China_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics" title="China at the 1952 Summer Olympics">since 1952</a>. China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in Beijing, where its athletes received 51 gold medals – <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics_medal_table" title="2008 Summer Olympics medal table">the highest number of gold medals</a> of any participating nation that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeo_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeo-570">[548]</a></sup> China also won the most medals of any nation at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Paralympics" title="2012 Summer Paralympics">2012 Summer Paralympics</a>, with 231 overall, including 95 gold medals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[549]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[550]</a></sup> In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a> in Guangdong, China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2011_Summer_Universiade" title="2011 Summer Universiade">2011 Summer Universiade</a>. China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2013_East_Asian_Games" title="2013 East Asian Games">2013 East Asian Games</a> in Tianjin and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="2014 Summer Youth Olympics">2014 Summer Youth Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a>. Beijing and its nearby city <a href="/wiki/Zhangjiakou" title="Zhangjiakou">Zhangjiakou</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebei_province" title="Hebei province">Hebei province</a> will also collaboratively host the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2022_Olympic_Winter_Games" title="2022 Olympic Winter Games">2022 Olympic Winter Games</a>, which will make Beijing the first city in the world to hold both the Summer Olympics and the Winter Olympics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[551]</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the official <a href="/wiki/Orders_of_precedence_in_China" title="Orders of precedence in China">Orders of precedence in China</a> (i.e. party comes first), the order of Wang would be inferior to the members of the Standing Committee of Politburo of CPC as he was not appointed office in the 19th Central Committee.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The area given is the official United Nations figure for <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">the mainland</a> and excludes <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_Stat_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Stat-16">[10]</a></sup> It also excludes the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Karakoram_Tract" title="Trans-Karakoram Tract">Trans-Karakoram Tract</a> (5,800 km<sup>2</sup> or 2,200 sq mi), <a href="/wiki/Aksai_Chin" title="Aksai Chin">Aksai Chin</a> (37,244 km<sup>2</sup> or 14,380 sq mi) and other territories in dispute with India. The total area of China is listed as 9,572,900 km<sup>2</sup> (3,696,100 sq mi) by the <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[11]</a></sup> For further information, see <a href="/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China">Territorial changes of the People's Republic of China</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This figure was calculated using data from the CIA World Factbook.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-19">[12]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Dollar" title="Hong Kong Dollar">Hong Kong Dollar</a> is used in <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> while the <a href="/wiki/Macanese_pataca" title="Macanese pataca">Macanese pataca</a> is used in Macau only.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Except <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The total area ranking relative to the United States depends on the measurement of the total areas of China and the United States. See <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">List of countries and dependencies by area</a> for more information.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"[...] Next vnto this, is found the great China, whose kyng is thought to bee the greatest <a href="/wiki/Prince" title="Prince">prince</a> in the worlde, and is named Santoa Raia".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[33]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"[...] The Very Great Kingdom of China".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[34]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">...O Grande Reino da China...</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[35]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Eden used the now obsolete form <i>Chinish</i>: "...whence the Chinishe nation haue theyr prouision for shppyng..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[38]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although this is the present meaning of <i><i lang="zh-Latn-pinyin" title="Chinese language text">guó</i></i>, in <a href="/wiki/Old_Chinese" title="Old Chinese">Old Chinese</a> (when its pronunciation was something like <span class="nowrap">/*qʷˤək/</span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bs_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-bs-60">[46]</a></sup> it meant the walled city of the Chinese and the areas they could control from them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-61">[47]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-64">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Its use is attested from the 6th-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classic_of_History" title="Classic of History">Classic of History</a>, which states "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian_(god)" title="Tian (god)">Huangtian</a> bestowed the lands and the peoples of the central state to the ancestors" (<span lang="zh" title="Chinese language text">皇天既付中國民越厥疆土于先王</span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[48]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Owing to Qin Shi Huang's earlier policy involving the "<a href="/wiki/Burning_of_books_and_burying_of_scholars" title="Burning of books and burying of scholars">burning of books and burying of scholars</a>", the destruction of the confiscated copies at Xianyang was an event similar to the <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_the_Library_of_Alexandria" title="Destruction of the Library of Alexandria">destructions</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Alexandria" title="Library of Alexandria">Library of Alexandria</a> in the west. Even those texts that did survive had to be painstakingly reconstructed from memory, luck, or forgery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[73]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Old_Texts" title="Old Texts">Old Texts</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Five_Classics" title="Five Classics">Five Classics</a> were said to have been found hidden in a wall at the Kong residence in <a href="/wiki/Qufu" title="Qufu">Qufu</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mei_Ze" title="Mei Ze">Mei Ze</a>'s "rediscovered" edition of the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Documents" title="Book of Documents">Book of Documents</a> was <a href="/wiki/Yan_Ruoqu" title="Yan Ruoqu">only shown to be a forgery in the Qing dynasty</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-162">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>, the total area of the United States, at 9,522,055 km<sup>2</sup> (3,676,486 sq mi), is slightly smaller than that of China. Meanwhile, the CIA World Factbook states that China's total area was greater than that of the United States until the coastal waters of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> was added to the United States' total area in 1996. From 1989 through 1996, the total area of US was listed as 9,372,610 km<sup>2</sup> (3,618,780 sq mi) (land area plus inland water only). The listed total area changed to 9,629,091 km<sup>2</sup> (3,717,813 sq mi) in 1997 (with the Great Lakes areas and the coastal waters added), to 9,631,418 km<sup>2</sup> (3,718,711 sq mi) in 2004, to 9,631,420 km<sup>2</sup> (3,718,710 sq mi) in 2006, and to 9,826,630 km<sup>2</sup> (3,794,080 sq mi) in 2007 (territorial waters added).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-166"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-166">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">China's border with Pakistan and part of its border with India falls in the disputed region of <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a>. The area under Pakistani administration is claimed by India, while the area under Indian administration is claimed by Pakistan.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-408"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-408">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Tsung-Dao_Lee" title="Tsung-Dao Lee">Tsung-Dao Lee</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobel_Physics_1957_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Physics_1957-403">[384]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chen_Ning_Yang" title="Chen Ning Yang">Chen Ning Yang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nobel_Physics_1957_403-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Physics_1957-403">[384]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_C._Tsui" title="Daniel C. Tsui">Daniel C. Tsui</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[385]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Charles_K._Kao" title="Charles K. Kao">Charles K. Kao</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[386]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yuan_T._Lee" title="Yuan T. Lee">Yuan T. Lee</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[387]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tu_Youyou" title="Tu Youyou">Tu Youyou</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[388]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-509"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-509">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The national life expectancy at birth rose from about 31 years in 1949 to 75 years in 2008,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[487]</a></sup> and infant mortality decreased from 300 per thousand in the 1950s to around 33 per thousand in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref_abcu_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcu-508">[488]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-530"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-530">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Emperor" title="Yellow Emperor">Yellow Emperor</a> (<i>Huangdi</i> 黄帝) is often presented as the ancestor of both <a href="/wiki/Zhonghua_minzu" title="Zhonghua minzu">Chinese people</a> and Chinese civilization. In Chinese religion, he embodies or grasps the <i><a href="/wiki/Axis_mundi" title="Axis mundi">axis mundi</a></i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kunlun_Mountain_(mythology)" title="Kunlun Mountain (mythology)">Kunlun Mountain</a>), the hub of creation, identifying with the <a href="/wiki/Absolute_(philosophy)" title="Absolute (philosophy)">spring of the universe</a> (天 <i><a href="/wiki/Tian" title="Tian">Tiān</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fowler_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fowler-529">[508]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

<li id="cite_note-imf.org-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-imf.org_24-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf.org_24-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf.org_24-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf.org_24-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="http://www.imf.org/external/datamapper/datasets/WEO/1" rel="nofollow">"IMF Data Mapper"</a>. <li id="cite_note-NBS2015-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NBS2015_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/PressRelease/201601/t20160119_1306072.html" rel="nofollow">"China's Economy Realized a Moderate but Stable and Sound Growth in 2015"</a>. National Bureau of Statistics of China. 19 January 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2016</span>. <q>Taking the per capita disposable income of nationwide households by income quintiles, that of the low-income group reached 5,221 yuan, the lower-middle-income group 11,894 yuan, the middle-income group 19,320 yuan, the upper-middle-income group 29,438 yuan, and the high-income group 54,544 yuan. The Gini Coefficient for national income in 2015 was 0.462.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=China%27s+Economy+Realized+a+Moderate+but+Stable+and+Sound+Growth+in+2015&amp;rft.pub=National+Bureau+of+Statistics+of+China&amp;rft.date=2016-01-19&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.stats.gov.cn%2Fenglish%2FPressRelease%2F201601%2Ft20160119_1306072.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-131"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-131">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Tien, Hung-mao (1991). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xCxMn-2msr8C&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow">"Constitutional Reform and the Future of the Republic of China"</a>. <li><cite class="citation book">Sang Ye (2006). <i>China Candid: The People on the People's Republic</i>. <a href="/wiki/University_of_California_Press" title="University of California Press">University of California Press</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-520-24514-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-520-24514-3">978-0-520-24514-3</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=China+Candid%3A+The+People+on+the+People%27s+Republic&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-520-24514-3&amp;rft.au=Sang+Ye&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></li>

New York: Monthly Review Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-85345-532-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-85345-532-5">978-0-85345-532-5</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+People%27s+Republic+of+China%3A+Documentary+History+of+Revolutionary+Change&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Monthly+Review+Press&amp;rft.date=1979&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-85345-532-5&amp;rft.aulast=Selden&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AChina"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_BRICS_leaders" title="List of BRICS leaders">Leaders</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="504" data-file-width="720" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/33px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/43px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" width="22"/></span> <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Temer</a></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">History</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Regional variants</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/African_socialism" title="African socialism">African</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Arab_socialism" title="Arab socialism">Arab</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Britain%27s_Road_to_Socialism" title="Britain's Road to Socialism">British</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Burmese_Way_to_Socialism" title="Burmese Way to Socialism">Burmese</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">Chinese</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Labor_Zionism" title="Labor Zionism">Israeli</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Melanesian_socialism" title="Melanesian socialism">Melanesian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sandinista_ideology" title="Sandinista ideology">Nicaraguan</a></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div>
<ol><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China">Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China</a>, participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".</li>
<li>Officially the Republic of China, participates as "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu</a>", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.</li></ol>

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Other</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
